titleStmt.title: The scowrers a comedy : acted by Their Majesties servants / written by Tho. Shadwell ...
titleStmt.author: Shadwell, Thomas, 1642?-1692.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in British Library.

div.p: THE SCOWRERS. A COMEDY, Acted by Their Majesties Servants.
Written by THO. SHADWELL, Poet Laureat, and Historiographer-Royal.
LONDON: Printed for Iames Knapton, at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-yard. 1691.

div.head: Drammatis Personae.

row.cell: A City Wit and Scowrer, imitator of Sir William.
Wife to Sir Richard, Mother to Eugenia.

div.p: Glazier, Vintner, Drawers, Fidlers, Tradesmen, Duns, Constable, Watchmen, Buttler, and Footmen.

lg.l: SCowrers! Methinks I hear some Ladies say,
How shall we bear the lewdness of this Play!
The Author begs the Title may not fright,
Of what he does to vertuous Ladies write.
Others for guilt may blush, or rag● look pale,
And, as they us'd, maliciously may rail.
Tho he exposes Vice, the Play's 〈◊〉 clean,
The nicest shall not tax it for Obscene:
Though some have been so ticklish in the Mind,
They could find Bawdy, which he ne're design'd:
Nor can he think he gave the least occasion,
Wanting their Vigour of Imagination;
But they, their ends had in their false reports,
And frightn'd whom he most would please, the Court;
To you he appeals, the Witty, Fair, and Good;
Whose soveraign power can never be withstood,
To all the Audience be bid me say,
He of the Gout lay in, and of this Play
Not long continu'd his Poetick Fit,
The other grief he cannot part with yet,
But give him case, and let who will have Wit.
Your kind Indulgence sure he ought to gain,
Who for your pleasure writes in spight of Pain:
You have been kind to many of his Plays,
And shou'd not leave him in his latter days.
Though Loyal Writers of the last two Reigns,
Who tir'd their Pens for Popery and Chains;
Grumble at the Reward of all his Pains:
They would, like some, the benefit enjoy,
Of what they vilely labour'd to destroy.
They cry him down as for his place unfit,
Since they have all the humour and the Wit,
They must write better e're he fears them yet;
Till they have shown you more Variety,
Of natural, unstoln Comedy than he,
By you at least he should Protected be.
Till then may he that Mark of Bounty have,
Which his renown'd and Royal Master gave;
Who loves a Subject and contemns a Slave,
Whom Heav'n in spight of Hellish plots design'd,
To humble Tyrants, and exalt Mankind.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir William Rant in his Morning-Gown, and Ralph his Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I Am plaguy qualmish this morning, we drunk swingingly last night, what did we do? tell me the History.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Must every Morning be spent in asking Questions? 'tis a fine life, you'le sin over Night, and I must come to Confession next Morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Sirrah, Know I will have no Wit nor Wisdom from you.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I don't know what you call Wit, but certainly Wisdom will never agree with that hot head of yours, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You solid Lump of Massy Phlegm! there is no such blessing under Heaven, as a hot Head.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: 'Twill cost you and your Companions dear before you part with it; the Devil on't is, you are always the Transgressor, and I never fail of being the Penitent.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sirrah, The Inside of thy Loggerhead will endanger the Outside, if thou begin not thy Narrative immediately; some Action in the forepart of night, I remember, but the latter part is all Darkness to me: Yet it runs in my head we had a Fray.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: And don't you feel it in your Shoulders? I am sure you've Reason, so have I.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Where was it?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why here, in Covent-Garden. You would needs have a Skirmish with some drunken Bullies, awkward, roaring, blustering Rascals: And Brigadier Stokes with a detachment of Quarter-Staves, and rusty▪ Halberts fell in Pell Mell and routed both Parties.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: That damn'd Quarter-staff Rogue would be universal Monarch of the Night; We must confederate and humble him, but what execution was there? Whose Skull crackt? whose Lungs pierced? or who lustily bruised.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: One of the Bullies has a good lusty flesh wound, the other are a little hackt, but all of them wer carryed Captive to the Round-house, where they have solaced with Ale and Brandy all night long: Two of your Footmen with bloody Coxcombs, were likewise in Limbo: Two or three of the Watchmen have slight hurts, which they are ready to swear are mortal; But your Friends Mr. Tope and Mr Wildfire are escap'd unhurt, save a little dry beating which indeed we seldom fail of.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
An Evening very handsomely spent; I am glad the Bullies are maul'd. I would rejoyce as much to run an English Bully through, as an Irish
Rapparee. The City ought to pay a certain number of Bullies heads a tribute to the Government, as the Welsh did Wolves; but see my Footmen ransom'd.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: They are bayl'd by your Taylor, and dress'd by your Surgeon, and are ready to be drunk, and scower again, Sir, but that was not all, that happened last night, 'twould take a Volume to write the History of your Actions one week.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: We should be diligent, I love an active life, but what more?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why, in your retreat homewards you pick'd up a Strumpet! I must needs say not very handsome, nor over well drest, nor extreamly sober, nor extraordinary clean, and made me put her to bed in your own Bed, I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Well, thou art a faithful Bawd.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Bawd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes Bawd Sir, what a Devil dost thou think I keep thee for thy neat parts? Indeed thou art a little stout.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Any man but my Master, should find I were a great deal so, if he talk'd thus to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Well well Sir, but where is the Whore?

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.l: I believe where she should be, at the civil Recreation of Hemp-beating.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Pox on your Impertinence! How got she out?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why truly Sir, after you had taken your wonted Nap in your Chair, recover'd a little, and came to your Bed-side, you puk'd at the sight of her, ask'd her how she had the Impudence to bring so ugly a Countenance along with her under your Roof: To all Entreaties were inexorable, you tore her out of the bed, flung her clothes out of the window, and made me turn her naked out of the house.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: 'Twas a very impudent thing of an ugly Jade to come hither.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: She pick'd up her Clothes, but was in great want of a Tiring-room; and most certainly fell into the enemies hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Well, and I have never a wench this morning?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Here have been five or six, they all said they'd come again.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pox on 'em, come again! but into whose hands may they fall before they come again? I hate even a Rose, after it opens in the morning, and is ruffled by the wind.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Your provident, prudent, and pious House-keeper has lodged two who came last night, for peace sake, in two several apartments of your Seraglio, not knowing which of them you would vouchsafe your Handkerchief to.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: She has done wisely, I will have them both: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Mrs. Haughty and Mrs. Mavis.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh pox they'll never draw together. But go into my Closet and fetch me a bottle of Spirit of Clary, and a lusty Glass.

Now is my Father I warrant grieving in the Country bewailing my lewd courses: To say truth, I cannot but love him, he has been very indulgent to me; but methinks he should have the conscience to remember his own youthful gambols; Tope tells me he knew him almost as lewd a fellow as my self.
But the worst of all is I am in love, most desperate most abominable love, the worst of all love, I am afraid honest love.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Here's your Spirit of Clary.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Set it down, and see what confounded [A great noise of talking and knocking without. noise that is without. The Devil take 'em, must I be always interrupted in my rest or my pleasure? a man had as good be a great man as a Drunkard at this rate.
Well what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The noise you are pretty well us'd to; an assembly of Duns, Whores and Bawds, as there are every morning at your Levee.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hail, hail my dear Companions of the night, Iack Tope and Tom Wildfire.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: My dear Knight, my dear Will Rant, thou art the Prince of Drunkards and of Scowrers; thou art a noble Seavenger, and every night thou clearest the streets of scoundrel Bullies, and of idle Rascals; and of all Aletosts and sops in Brandy.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: And the Taverns of Trades-men and of sober Rogues of business, who should be at their cheating callings, or watching of their Wives at home.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I am glad to find you so hearty, and that ye suffer'd so little in our last nights rout.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: I will not wear like a Bully my arm in a Scarf as a sign of battel past▪ when perhaps the wound is no bigger than that of a Lancet in letting blood; I have seen danger in my life time.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Yes and felt it too to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Puh this is nothing, why I knew the Hectors, and before thom the Muns and the Titire Tu's, they were brave fellows indeed; in those days a man could not go from the Rose Tavern to the Piazza once, but he must venture his life twice. My dear Sir Willy.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, and the Wine was better, and the Women handsomer; you old fellows are always magnifying the days of your youth.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Old! Gad take me, hem, hem; here's a body sound wind and limb! Old! quoth he. Indeed I have drank off two generations, and intend to drink off three more yet. Why I wench'd, drunk and scowr'd with thy Father, Will: He was a pretty fellow in his youth, and I thought he would have come to something, but he married and run into the Country, left our noble cause, and grew a very wise, discreet, vertuous Country Jobbernoll.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Why you debauch'd with my Grandfather.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: I knew him in his ebb: but thy Father, Tom, was a sober for a consumptive Scoundrel, and we could make nothing of him, he married like a Puppy, and grew most pitifully uxorious, but the comfort is few of that sort get their own Children: Thou art not like him at all.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, I never remember him, Providence took care of me in good time.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Here Ralph fill. Gentlemen, a health to my Mistriss in a brimmer of Clary.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: I defy mornings Draughts, besides Spirits will bring you from two pound of Peef, to two poatch'd Eggs, trust an experienc'd Drunkard, thou will not I've out half thy days, if thou tak'st these lewd courses of drinking in a Morning.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: But we will live out all our Nights.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: I have buried two hundred Mornings draught-men of my Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You may well kill 'em if you drink not fair with them; but thou hast kill'd as many Evenings Draught-men too. Never Hero in Romance kill'd more in his Adventures.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Their Deaths be upon their own Heads, I preserved my self: why I have been walking two hours in the Park.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The Deaths of these men lie upon his Conscience, and he cannot sleep.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, no, he wants the dear Balsom of his Youthful blood, that balmy soveraign Juice that sends kind vapours up to rock the brain; Here, I will have my Mistriss pledged.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Thy Mistriss! ha ha ha, why every one in a Petticoat is thy Mistriss, from humble Bulker to exalted Countess.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: No I am particular, damnably particular, why I am fallen in love.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: In Love! What a Devil! That is, thou hast a plaguy mind to some Wench; I have known thee have that to many a Damsel, but when thou hast gotten her, thou never sail'st to leave either her, or a child by her, to the Parish.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why those kind of Ladies come to the Parish at last, and the sooner they take care of them the better, it is a good settled kind of Life. But this is a Lady of Quality.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: A pox of a Whore of Quality; they are ten times more troublesome, and not handsomer than poor Whores.

sp.speaker: Sir. Will.
sp.l: A whore! this is a Saint.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Saint! ha ha ha, a world of Saints there are in these days, but very few honest.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I can scarce forbear to worship her, and call her Nymph; divine, Goddess.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Nymph! divine, Goddess! ha ha ha, language for a young Coxcombly Chaplain to his Ladies waiting woman.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Love! Faith I could never believe there was any such thing: I have had a furious Appetite to a new Face, like a greedy stomach to a new Dish, but I never made a very full meal, but I wish'd it off again.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Love! Why what a Pox, I have had as many Whores as any of you; but I never had one whom I car'd if she were hang'd or no.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Oh base, gross Appetites, of ill-natur'd Fellows.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh thou Flower of Civility, and good Nature! I never knew you, or any Whore-master, but minded himself, and never car'd what became of the woman, why prithee don't we ruin all we have to do with?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Some few keeping Coxcombs indeed are undone by them; but that grows much out of Fashion, because keep what you can, Particular Whores will soon grow Commons ones.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hence all such profane thoughts, this is a Lady, who has all the Beauty and Vertue of the Sex.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Pish, Sex savst thou? I warrant she is not over stock'd neither if she has; but Beauty is frail, and Vertue is more frail, Will.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Away with your babbling, Tom here's to her, take a Glass.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Come Iack her Health.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: God not I! I would not drink the Queens health fasting, not I; charge a bill upon me, and I'le answer you in a couple of brimmers of Claret at Lockets at dinner, where I have bespoken an admirable good one for ye; but my Wine shall always have something to feed upon.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Here are a company of Letters, some are waiting for answers.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: From Whores, all Whores.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hah! they are so, some in distress I suppose: Like a true great man, I will put Petitions in my pocket and never read 'em.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Sir the Duns are very noisy, and will not be kept out.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Obstinate Rogues that will fling away their precious time so.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: But there's a pert dapper fellow whom I know not, he will not be denyed.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Let him in first. How now, who are you?

sp.speaker: Glaz.
sp.p: And please your Worship I am a Glazier, and have an humble petition to your Worship; your Glazier dyed within this hour, the bell now goes for him; and I humbly desire I may succeed in your Worships work.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Thou act a very pretty fellow.

sp.speaker: Glaz.
sp.p: I waited for this happy occasion, and hoped for't so I made him drink like a Fish, and treated him with brandy. The man indeed was an honest man, but alack, alack! he had little to do for a long time, till your business and your friends, Sir, brought him into request: He has had a fine time under you; for your Worship I understand has to Shash-windows an utter aversion, Sir, when you are in beer.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: A very pretty discreet fellow.

sp.speaker: Glaz.
sp.p: Why Sir he bore Offices, maintain'd his wife with all things about her, and now dyes well to pass, and for all may thank your Worship. Now if your Worship will let me have the place, I shall see that all the Parish, when you please to break their windows, shall have as good goods as any man can furnish 'em with.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Let me see, this place must be worth Money.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Let me speak with you, I can do your business.

sp.speaker: Glaz.
sp.l: I will Sir; but Sir do they sell places now adays?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Oh no no, Heaven forbid! thou shalt have it for nothing.

sp.speaker: Glaz.
sp.l: Thank you, sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.
sp.stage: Ralph holds his hand out behind him, the Glazier puts Money into it, and Ex▪

sp.speaker: Glaz.
sp.l: Ay Sir, there and please you.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: A pox on him, a thirteen pence half penny▪ but I'll after him, and squeeze the Sponge, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come let in the Canaille, the Rabble of my Anti-chamber, my Duns, &c. Now will I behave my self statelily, impudently, and do no mans business but my own.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Sir Humphry Maggot has sent word he'll wait on you e're you go out.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: That's the Coxcombly Alderman that marry'd my termagant Aunt; her first Husband was my Fathers brother by the second venter. She has this dolt under correction, sweet Princess; and has forced him out of Mark-lane to live in Soho Square. I warrant some old lecture from my Daddy. Let the Duns enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now Rogues, Rascals, Vermin, Catterpillers, Duns, come on; I will use you so like Duns for plaguing me with so many dayly visits, I say, I will use you so like Duns.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Humphry Maggot and observes them.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: That is send them away without Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You silly impudent Puppies, to come to me for summs fit for Haberdashers of small Wares to pay, ridiculous, petty summs, come up to bulky ones, either in valuable Goods or Mony, fit for a Gentlemans consideration, and Security may follow.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Here's a Spark, thank Heaven I have kept my Nephew at the Inns of Court, whom I bred up, free from his lewd Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why I never pay a bill till it be as long as an account in Chancery, you Rogues, Dogs:

sp.speaker: Duns altogether.
sp.p: Why we ask but for our own Sir. I hope a man may ask for his own Sir. My Goods were my own Sir, my own. Very fine a man must not ask for his own. Rogues for asking for a mans own?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And Rogues I will make you know this House is my own, which I will signifie to you by this Foot which is my own, and by this Cudgel which is my own.
sp.stage: Sir William kicks and cudgels them out.

sp.speaker: Duns.
sp.p: Fly, fly, Murther, murther. May not ask for his own, my own. Murther, Murther. For my own, help, Murther.
sp.stage: (In running out they run down the (Alderman.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Gad forgive me, Help help.

sp.speaker: Sir. Will.
sp.p: Oh Sir Humphrey I cry you mercy, I was at my Morning Exercise, disciplining my Rogues, my Duns.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Duns, Sir Will. Rant? let me tell you Duns may be very honest men.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hum, so you Citizens are apt to think, but we Gentlemen believe no such matter. But come I know you have some wise Lecture from nown Daddy, or some such business, come out with it, I stand fair.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman! my heart bleeds for him, you make him miserable with your extravagant lewd Life, he writes me word you got the Parsons daughter with Child, when you were at home last, and now she is near her time she names you for the Father, this is the strangest thing that ever was.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not at all, it had been strange if she had gotten me with Child; the Parsons are lusty, lazy, well sed Fellows, and will be too hard for the Laity, if we don't take Letters of Reprisal upon them.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Save us Heaven! I would not have my Nephew Whachum acquainted with you for the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Nor I with him Sir Nump, I keep somewhat better Company, you have seen my Friends here.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Yes an I heard of them too, the Nation rings of'em, my Lady my Wife and your Aunt is perpetually grieving and sighing for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha, good Lady! Nuncle look to thy City Forehead, there are those who can graft and inoculate.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: She has kept her two Daughters (she had by your half Uncle) in the Country these five years, for fear you should come to her House and bring a scandal upon them.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: But they are now in Town, to my cost I find it (aside) Oh that dear, sweet Eugenia! she has kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pox on this Blockhead he grows tedious; to your Cue: Has Monsieur Catinat given the Vaudois such a bang?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Undoubtedly, there's a World of News in Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Hold hold Gentlemen, I beseech you hold, News say you? have a little Patience Sir William, here's a Letter from your Father, I have had it ever since the last Post, and you have not been at home till this Morning. But pray Gentlemen what News is of Master Catinat? I love News extreamly, I have read Three News Letters to day, I go from Coffee-House to Coffee-House all day on purpose. I talk'd with as pretty a man, of a News Writer, as any in London, and of as neat parts, as bold a Fellow, he cares not what he writes. But he knew nothing of the Vaudois this Morning.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: They are soundly beaten, almost all cut off.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Heaven be praised, they are damn'd Presbyterian Fellows, and hate the Church, for my part, had I my will, I would put all the Phanaticks in Christendom in pitch'd shirts, light them, and let them blaze like City Funerals. But hold, is it true that Prince Waldeck is dead of a Feaver?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Oh yes, and he got it with scowring at the Canal at Bruges.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph,
sp.p: Goodlack! Teckely and the Cossacks upon the Ukrain have totally routed Prince Lewis of Baden, and cut his Army all to pieces, Well this Louys is the bravest King.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: The old Gentleman is very prolix.
sp.p: Lewd courses— great affliction— hum: have I been so kind. Very well.
Your wicked extravagance will kill me. Ha ha ha, kill! not these Twenty years, if Heaven takes no better care of me I shall be in a pretty case.
But this Action of the Parsons daughter. Pray Heaven the old man got her not himself, for her Mother was my Mothers Woman. Pish pox this is stuff, I would the old Gentleman would spare his pains.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Oh impious! what tear your Fathers Letter?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes when they are nothing to the purpose: I sent to him for a lusty summ of Money, and he sends me a parcel of wise Councel that is not worth a Farthing.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: But Sir the other News you were speaking of.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why 'tis most certain Catinat has laid a bridge over the Rhine and secured his passage into France, and another over the Mosell to secure his pass into Italy,

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Well that Master Catinat is a very pretty man, he'll soon destroy the Presbyterians and burn that Anti-christian Town of Geneva. Oh this Louis is a glorious Prince, what would I give to see him, I believe I might have a pass to go over to be touch'd for the Evil, He must needs do it rarely.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well said old Grumble, have you no wise advice from my Aunt? she will have you under Correction if you deliver it not.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: poor Lady, she grieves that you should drink and roar, and beat the whole Town and spend your Money upon ugly Whores. But pray what News of Buda?
sp.stage: Enter Mrs. Mavis and Mrs. Haughty at two several doors.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Now they are both gotten up, Wars will ensue.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hold hold Nuncle, ugly Whores say you? be you Judge, who keeps the uglier Whores my Aunt or I?

sp.speaker: Haughty.
sp.l: Oh impudence! another in the House, oh oh.
sp.stage: They both fall in 2 Chairs in Fits.

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Oh Devil I cannot endure this, oh oh.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Gad forgive me, look to the Gentlewomen, look to the Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now my dear Friends let's go quickly now now, I love to leave Whores in Fits mightily.
sp.stage: [Ex. Sir Will. Tope, Wildfire and Ralph.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Gad take me! hold the Gentlewomen, bring some cold water, and flower, burn some blew inkle and Partridge Feathers, 'tis my Ladies Medicine.

sp.speaker: Haughty.
sp.l: Is the Villain gone?

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Is the Rogue fled?

sp.speaker: Haughty.
sp.l: Oh you Flirts I'le pluck your Eyes out.
sp.stage: They fight and tear one another.

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: I'le tear you Limb from Limb.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gad forgive me! help help, part them, they are incens'd, why Ladies, Gentlewomen, keep the peace, I charge ye in the Kings Name, I am of the Quorum.
sp.stage: Enter Housekeeper with her Spectacles in one hand, and the Ladies calling in the other.

sp.speaker: Haughty
sp.l: Oh Impudence!

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Thou common thing.

sp.speaker: Haughty.
sp.l: Go Iezabel, go.

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Avoid paint and wash!

sp.speaker: Haughty.
sp.l: Go pitiful Creature.

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Creature! creature in the very face of thee.

sp.speaker: Haughty.
sp.l: The Town knows what thou art.

sp.speaker: Mavis
sp.l: What am I, Ione? What do they know of me?

sp.speaker: Abigal.
sp.p: In truth you are to blame, to disturb a civil well order'd Family thus, well were it not for good Books that comfort me, I could never bear such exorbitances.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Ha, The Ladies calling, a very Matronly Gentlewoman truly.

sp.speaker: Abigal.
sp.l: But these godly books quiet the Conscience mightily.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Hah good Soul!

sp.speaker: Haughty.
sp.l: Let me come at her.
I'le tear her Throat out.

sp.speaker: Haught.
sp.l: Bawd, bawd.

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Thou art old enough to be my Mother.

sp.speaker: Haughty,
sp.l: Let me come at her.

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Let me come at her.

sp.speaker: Abigail.
sp.p: In truth Ladies you are much to blame, cannot you be civil? take them away separately.

sp.speaker: Haug.
sp.l: Whore, whore, whore, whore.
sp.stage: They hale them out at several doors.

sp.speaker: Mavis.
sp.l: Whore, whore, whore, whore.
sp.stage: Sir Humphrey takes the House-keeper under the Arm, and leads her out

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: WHat account shall I give of my Charge, and Guardianship? my Lady sends you out under my prudent conduct, as I may say, to look after Commodes and Top knots, with a flat Injunction not to see this lewd place, the Park.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Did she so old Mumpsimus?

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.p: And you in Contempt of her soveraign power, and my lawful authority under her, presume to come hither; what shall I do? what shall I say?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Can flesh and blood forbear this sweet, this most delicious place?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Flesh and Blood! Yes, it is a place fit for the carrying on the designs of flesh and blood indeed.

sp.speaker: Eug:
sp.l: And what dost thou take us for Spirits, Woman?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Come come Gentlewomen, my Lady is a wise woman: This is the Exchange for Lovers: Here they meet, and if they absent themselves are lookt upon as broken; nay worse, it is the Rendevouz of Fornicators and Adulterers.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Tis the Rendevouz of all who have sense enough to love the delicatest place on Earth.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: But I have a secret to tell you, it concerns you Madam Clara, I have found from Sir Humphrey your Father in Law, that he has made a match between his Nephew Mr. Whachum and you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: The Devil he shall! there's a mechanick thing, there is not such an odious creature as a City Spark.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Don't you trouble your self, his Uncle says you are not sober enough for him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nor I fool enough for him, I thank Heaven, a filthy City wit, those Fellows are as lewd as the Gentlemen every whit, only more impudent, foolish and ill-manner'd.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
Dear Clara thou art in the right, when a man is lewd with a bon Grace
there's something in it; but a Fellow that is aukwardly wicked is not to be born.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: He wicked! why he is a Student of the Inns of Court, Madam Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well you had a great secret for my Sister, and I have one for you: In short we are both resolv'd not to endure any longer the intolerable Yoke of Arbitrary power, under which we have so long groan'd, if you will comply, one or both of us will provide for you:

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And preserve you from making Night-caps or footing Stockings in a Garret, the pitiful remnant of thy decrepid Life.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Oh times and manners! will you break loose from all Government? I shall be undone, what will my Lady say, if she knows that you saw your Cozen Rant here yesterday?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Mutter no more under thy Gums, old Sybil I did see my Cozen yesterday, and I hope to see him this day, and every day of my life; keep your distance, we that are resolv'd to cast off my Mothers Tyranny, will no longer suffer thy Insolence.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: What will become of poor me?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: We are true English women, Co-heirs of two thousand pounds a year, and are resolv'd to assert our Liberty and Property.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Does my Mother think she shall mew us up any more, at her Jointure house, old Doe little?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Amongst poor innocent country things, who never stir beyond the Parish but to some Fair.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Did she not bestow good breeding upon you there?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: Breeding! what to learn to feed Ducklings, and cram Chickens?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: To see Cows milkd, learn to churn, and make cheese?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: To make clouted cream, and whipt Sillabubs?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: To make a Caraway Cake, and raise Py-crust?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: And to learn the top of your skill in Syrrup, Sweat-meats, Aqua mirabilis, and Snayl water.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Or your great cunning in Cheese-cakes, several Creams and Almond-butter.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Ay ay, and 'twere better for all the Gentlemen in England if their Wives had no other breeding, but you had Musick and Dancing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes an ignorant, illiterate hopping Puppy, that rides his dancing Circuit thirty miles about, Lights off his tyred Steed, draws his Kit at a poor country creature, and gives her a Hich in her pace, that she shall never recover.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And for Musick an old hoarse singing man riding ten miles from his Cathedral to Quaver out the Glories of our Birth and State, or it may be a Scotch Song more hideous and barbarous than an Irish Cronan.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And another Musick-master from the next Town to teach one to twinkle out Lilly burlero upon an old pair of Virginals, that sound worse than a Tinkers kettle that he crys his work upon— we'll ha' no more on't, we are come up to London and common sense, and we defy thee and thy works.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Keep distance.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: Avoid thou that think'st because thou art old thou must be wise.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Avaunt we'll have no more to do with thee.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Attend.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Obey.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Be under good Discipline.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Be a towardly old Governess.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: We are free from this minute.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Never more to hear thy wise advice,

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: Thy old Saws, and foolish Sayings.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: We will pare our Nails on any day of the Week.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And do what we will upon Childermas day, oh my dear Sister! How happy are we to come to this most blessed Town, and these most heavenly walks.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: This Paradice of the world.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Oh this Cozen of ours, he is the prettyest man my Eyes e're yet beheld.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: But sure Eugenia thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yes I am mad, stark mad, in love with him, and will be mad.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Thou art mad indeed, in love with so wild a man?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Wild, never trouble thy self for that, my dear! I warrant thee I'le tame him, the wilder the better.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: This is stark staring madness, why this lewd Cozen of ours, they say, has had all the women in Town that are to be had for Love or Money.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Sayst thou so my Child? then will my conquest be the greater, and I shall triumph over all them he has had, and he will be the more likely to be constant to me whom he never had.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: A short Triumph 'twould be, till he can meet with another weak enough to be taken.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I would not give a Farthing for her that cannot secure the Conquest she has made: I will have him, and I am mistaken if he be not as fierce upon me, as I am upon him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Thou art a mad Girl, I would not fall in love with a wild Fellow of the Town, if he would Jointure me with the East-Indies.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I could not, would not, but have fallen in love with this wild Fellow of the Town, to have been Mistress of all the Gold and Jewels in both Indies.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Thou art only fit to be Spouse to some Ladies darling, who has been cocker'd with Cawdles by his Lady mother, bred under a very humble civil Tutor in the house, who is always in most profound awe of his Pupil, from whence to the University he goes, where Divines (for the great respect they have to some Livings in his gift) flatter and indulge him in what he thinks fit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: You are very merrily dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: From thence the Fop comes home, and sets up his rest upon Horses, and Dogs, rides for a place, grows a most furious Nimrod, and hunts perpetually.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Will the Alarum of your Tongue never be down?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Come let's walk, and see if we can spy this same dear, dear, wild, very wild cousin, come along.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.p: Mercy on me, the World's turn'd topsy turvy. My Lady will kill me: She is a very Fury, and when provok'd, nor man, woman nor child can stand in her way.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: My dear Rogues! Dear Dogs! Bluster and Dingboy! you are the bravest fellows that ever scowred yet.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: Dear Squire Whachum! If ever there was such soowring in High-Holbourn since 'twas built, may I never taste Nants-Brandy more at midnight.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.p: The Nation will ring of us; such Exploits! such Atchievements! Not a window left in all the Inns of Chancery; those Hives of Attorneys, those Suit-breeders, those Litigious Rogues, the Sons of Court-hand, Copy Paper and Green Wax.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Not a Tavern window in all the street has a Quarrel in it.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Then how we scowr'd the Market people, overthrew the Butter-women, defeated the Pippin-Merchants, wip'd out the Milk-scores, pull'd off the Door-knockers, Dawb'd the gilt Signs!

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.p: But a pox on't, we were confoundedly beaten by the Hellish Constable and his Posse of Scoundrel Dogs.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: That most Damnable Inflexible Prig that bound us over this morning must be toss'd in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Slit in the Nose, and suffer other operations not very agreeable to him.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: No, let's be brave, but not too brave, I'll pay for the Windows and all; my Head's broken, but no matter I'll not be dismay'd: Well, never men laugh'd and roar'd more: This same Flipp and Punch are rare drinks.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Nāy, I'll hang for't if there be a knot of better Laughers in England.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: We'll laugh with e're a gang in England for a thousand pound. Why laughing's all the joy of a mans life.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: Then we have scowr'd so magnanimously these three nights, that we were taken for Sir William Rant and his company.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Sir William? no, no; oh Sir William is the finest, compleatest Gentleman that ever wore a head.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: There are others, Squire, that shall be nameless.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Oh no, never talk on't: there will never be his Fellow. Oh had you seen him scowre as I did, oh so delicately, so like a Gentleman! how he clear'd the Rose-Tavern! I was there about Law business, compounding for a Bastard, and he and two fine Gentlemen came roaring in the handsomeliest, and the most genteely turn'd us all out of the Room, and swing'd us, and kick'd us about, I vow to Gad, 'twould have done your heart good to have seen it.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: l'faith did he? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Brave fellows! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Aye, was't not handsome, ha, ha, ha. And in a minutes time clear'd the whole house, and broke all the windows, beat the woman at the Bar, and swagger'd by themselves. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Peace, peace; hold, hold! Here he comes, with his brave Friends. Stand by, and observe. Look you there, look you there, there's a fine person! there's a compleat Gentleman!
sp.stage: Enter Sir William Rant, Wildfire and Tope.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: A good pretty man.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: The man's well enough, but Squire Whachum I say for all that.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: O fie fie, Pretty-man! well he shall be my pattern while I live, an't please Heaven. You shall see him, oh if did you but hear him swear and curse you'd be in love with him! He does 'em so like a Gentleman, while a company of ye here about the Town, pop out your Oaths like pellets out of Elder Guns. They come so easily, so sweetly from him, even like Musick from an Organ-Pipe.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What do they lay more upon us than we did? who the Devil should these be that scowre so to be taken for us?

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Puh, pox these must be some Scoundrels that prophane our noble actions with vile bungling imitation.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: A man wou'd think we need no imputative wickedness.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: These Mushroom Scowrers had best see they do it handsomely, and bring no disgrace upon us, or we may chance to whip some of 'em thro' the Lungs about that business.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Do you hear Bluster and Dingboy? Oh if Fate, and my own Industry, could ever make me like this Dear, this gallant, Sir William, I were at the end of my Ambition.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: 'Tis a hard thing to scowre naturally, and handsomely.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Every Puppy, now a-days, presumes to set up for a Drunkard; but there are more good qualities requisite to a Drunkard than to a Minister of State, or a deep Divine. I'll pick up fellows fit for great men every hour in the Streets, but a Drunkard.—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well said, Iack Tope, thou art in the right, he must be of Mien and Person not ungraceful, of pleasing Speech, sharp must his Wit be, and his Judgment solid.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: He must be chearful, easie, and well temper'd.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: He must be well bred have seen the World; learn'd, knowing, and retentive of a secret: He must have Truth and Courage.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: In short, he must be just such a fellow as thou art, if it be possible; while all thy Contemporaries have either Dyed, or left off, and grown sober Sots, thou still perseverest in generous Lewdness.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: He is only to blame a little, to brush up the Ladies so much, when he's an Ancient Gentleman, and knows his own ability.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Prithee Stripling, trouble not thy self with what I can do, I can make love enough to make a Husband or Gallant Jealous, and that's as good as any thing thou canst do.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Look you there now! Well, all Europe cannot show a knot of finer Wits, and braver Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Faith, they are pretty smart men.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: The Gentlemen, I must confess, are pretty Gentlemen; but time shall try. I'll say no more——

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have an adventure will separate as for a while; but this shall be our Randezvous.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis not fit for a Gentleman to be without an Adventure in this place, Iack Tope.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Pox o' your Whores! I come here to venture for a good stomach to my Calvert Salmon, and my Turbot; your lazy fellows lose the pleasure of the Park, you shou'd be here in a morning, and observe crowching Spaniels hastning to some great mans Levee, whom they wish hang'd; and lean, assiduous knaves of business running from Office to Office, to get all they can under the Government they hate.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How many Villains that wish the Government destroyed, yet crowd for places in it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Such Rogues can do the Government no harm if they be kept out. But Tope, if thou growst politick, and troublest thy self how matters go, thou art too solid for a Drunkard, and must knock off.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: I knock off! Gad I scorn your words, I'll bury two or three hundred of you. Hem, hem, I'll scowre in the Mall now, if you will, without the help of Spirit of Clary, fasting, and in cold blood: Come on, fall on, I need no provocations to Lewdness.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Hold hold, a Sayl! a sayl! Each part, and cruise about.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Adieu for a while.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: A while! a pox o' your damn'd Caterwauling: Think on the Turbott and the Calvert Salmon at Lockets.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Two a clock be the time.
sp.stage: Ex. Sir Wil. Rant, Wildfire and Tope.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Let's follow at a distance and observe 'em. They are the bravest Blades, and purest Witts in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.p: But hark you Squire, by their discourse, even now, they seem to be Whiggs.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Damn'd Whiggs methinks.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: I am afraid they are a little Whiggish; really 'tis a thousand pities, they have kept ill company.
sp.l: Cods me, here's my Uncle! Great souls contain your selves.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How Nephew! What you are never to be found in your Chamber of late: How will your studies go on at this rate?

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: I was not well this morning, and came to take a little air.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Air, say you? Is there not as good air in Westminster-hall? Yes, and a profitable air some find it. I went thither expecting to find you upon a Cricket, civilly taking Reports, I think they call 'em.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: In good time Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: In good time! Come mind your business, I have made a match for you with my wives second daughter; the first is a Mad-cap, I'll have nothing to do with her; but the second for my money. I have agreed with her Mother that you shall give 5000l.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: I am for the eldest, she is for a mad fellows. She will fall in love with me, and I'll marry her for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: How! What Companions are these?

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Students of the Temple Sir, hard Students, very hard Students.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Students of the Temple? they look like Students of White-Fryers.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Have a care what you say Sir? your words will be actionable, they study hard all nights, lye rough, and seldom go to bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Have they read the Year books?

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Read all all.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: The Devil o' bit, read quoth he?

sp.speaker: Bluster.
sp.p: Year books! I never read any thing but Gazettes, those are the week books.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen de'e hear any news ● I hear the Pope and the King of France are agreed.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: We hard Students never mind News, but that's very good.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Hold I see one that owes me Money, stay I'll come to you here and tell you more, I hope we are all honest.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: Oh aye.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Do you and they come dine with me then.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: A pox on him, he has hindered us observing these fine Gentlemen, let's walk, we shall lose them.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Maggot, after her Tope.

sp.speaker: Lady Magg.
sp.p: Are there no Gallants left? poor gentle love is now neglected, and all mens heads lye towards Knavery and Business. I have walk'd the whole length of the Mall alone, on purpose for an amorous Adventure, and met none; nor have had any observe me except this old Red nos'd, better'd Drunkard, and yet my shape and habit are enough inviting, besides some Jewels which I seem to conceal, and yet take care to expose, shew my Wealth and Quality sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: What solitary adventure is this? she is richly laden, I'll lay her on board with my two Pounders and my Patercras

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: That must be my sweet Duckling— I know her by her pretty waddle in her Gate— besides I have had a sight of her Rump Jewel: I know it— my Dear, my Chicken I know thee well enough.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Unlucky Omen for a Lady to be pick'd up by her own musty Husband first? How now, what old Fellow art thou?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come Chicken! don't think to bob thy own Dear, don't I know that Jewel?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Ha! This is the Aldermans Wife, I'le cuckold him, that's certain: I have not cuckolded an Alderman these 7 years. If honest Iack Tope 〈◊〉 live to be kept in his old Age? Hah!

sp.speaker: La Mag.
sp.l: Well Sneak-goose what then? what do you come poking hither for?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Come Chicken, I'le take a walk with thee.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: With me! I faith but you shall not, when did you ever see a Lady of my Quality walk with her own Husband? well I shall never reach a Citizen manners. I warrant you think you are in Moor-Fields seeing Haberdashers walking with their whole Fireside.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum.
sp.l: Prithee Chicken be appeas'd:

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Chicken! you are very familiar, what you would have the world believe you Jealous?

sp.speaker: Sir Hum.
sp.l: Who I Jealous? Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Besides a Lady of my Quality, that have so many great people of kin to me, to be seen with a pitiful mechanick Alderman. I have disgrac'd the Ancient Noble Family of the Rants enough already in marrying you. Be gone I say out of the Park.

sp.speaker: Sir. Humph.
sp.p: Well Chicken, thou wilt have thy own way, be not offended no more, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: So now have at her, pray Heaven she be sound— she's of Quality— hah! may be ne're the founder for that neither— Hail solitary Damsel! by thy pensive-walking I find thou art in Distress; and being a true Knight Errant, come to offer thee the succour of my person.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: Not in so much distress neither.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: These Vizards have all gotten a road of talking pertly and impudently, they learn it of the Beaux; come, I know what 'tis thou want'st; I am ready to pay a Bill at sight.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: What do you think I have a mind to drink a Bottle or two?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: No, thou pervese creature, thou knowst my meaning well enough; if thou wilt have me speak broad I can bear it, have at thee.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: Hold, hold, methinks you seem to be an Ancient Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Ancient! Gad take me, I am tough, and well season'd! All this last Generation were but half gotten, and have the Rickets.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: Do not grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Troublesome, Sweet-heart, be not foolish: Ah! thou knowst not what's in me.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: Yes, I suppose last Nights lewd Dose, and two Bottles this Morning: That an old Gentleman with one foot in the Grave should be thus lewd.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Ounds! I cou'd find in my heart to kick her; she has provok'd my choller more than ever she can raise my love. But I will dissemble, a whore she is, my whore I'll make her, that I may revenge the indignity, and use her scuryily. Come, my Dear, thou dost not take me for a Milk-sop, to accept of one denial— Have at her.
sp.l: — Women born to be controll'd,
Stoop to the forward and the bold.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Old Gentleman be civil.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Old agen! you women are for the young stripling that switch, and spur a short race like Citizens on May-day in the Park, but we solid Lovers are for the whole course, come come I know what you come for, and you shall not go without it— I'le carry you to a Friends Lodging— and I gad I'll, I'll— no more to be said.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: You are a sawcy old Fool, and I'll have you kickt.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall go, no matter for that.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Help, help, help!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Lady in Distress! Do you want my assistance? I am at your service— How now Iack, what Ravishing?

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: I see you are a man of Honour, a thousand thanks for delivering me from the Assaults of this Libidinous Goat. He is the finest Gentleman I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: So fine a Lady shall never want any Service I can do her.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Sweet Sir, really your manner is so obliging.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: These damn'd young Fellows, like Dutch Capers, will snap up all Adventurers, they have the better of us at cruising, we have no game to play at but ready Whore, ready Money.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You do me too much honour

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: O I am charm'd with him— (aside) You have so infinitely oblig'd me, that Sir I assure you I shall be always proud of it, and hope to see you at my house in Soho Square.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You make me blush at my little service: Alas that Gentleman may say what he will, he puts on a rough outside, but he is a very harmless man to a Lady as can be.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Prithee, now I see her Face take her and make your best on't.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Was there ever so rude a Person?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You know where you are Sir.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prithee Iack Tope dissemble a little, there's a trick in't, it shall turn to thy good.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Pox on her? I care not if she were hang'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Sir I beseech you engage not your Person in my Quarrel, if any hurt should come on't, I should for ever hate and curse my self.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not on my honour— this is Maggot the Aldermans wife, she has two pretty Daughters come to Town, and great Fortunes; besides tho she is declining, she is but a little on the other side of the Hill, and looks well and lusty.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Sir I fear you are meditating on Revenge upon that old Ruffian; I shall wish I had never been born, if I should engage so fine a Gentleman in danger, for that reason let me desire the honour of your walking with me while I am in the Mall, and afterwards if you please to protect me to my House; I shall there be able to make in some measure a return for this signal favour.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I am your Slave Madam, wholly at your disposal.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh lucky adventure! this was the happiest moment of my Life. aside. Who's here my Daughters Governess? Enter Pris. Caytiff what dost thou from thy charge? where are my Daughters?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: My charge, they have broken loose from me and defy'd me, and you too: They forc'd me to the Park, here they are taken up by a wild Fellow; who bid his Footmen seize on me and toss me in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh vile wretch! I'le strangle thee, I'le tear thy Windpipe out, where are they? speak, speak, speak.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Hold off your hands. you choke me, I can't speak.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Where where, you old Iudas?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: At the further end of the Mall.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Forgive my indecent passion, and let me beg your assistance— follow Beldame.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I wait on you Madam, this was a happy opportunity.
sp.stage: Enter Sir William Rant, Eugenia and Clara.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Dear Sister, Let's go, I tremble every Joynt, Oh if my Mother should see us?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Dear pretty Cozen know thy power, and desy the Tyranny of thy Mother.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The only man my Mother has perpetually warn'd us oss.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha! I am glad of that, she could not possibly have contriv'd better to bring us together. [Aside.] But dear Eugenia, thou sweetest creature that the Earth e're bore! consider thy own confinement, and my misery: There is not in a Dungeon such a wretch as I should be without thy kindness.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: What you take me for a poor weak country thing, as ready to be caught as any Fool you ever ruin'd yet; I'll make you know I am above your Arts.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You are to me what e're you please to be, but I to you must be the truest, and the heartiest Lover that ever Beauty was too hard for yet.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: You talk as if you were serious, can you imagine this will pass, how smoothly you rehearse it?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Tear out my heart and thou wilt find thy Image there:

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Fustian! rapture! said to a hundred tawdy things in a week. Can you think me so mad to fling my self away upon so notorious a lewd creature? 'Tis a certain ruin to be seen with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I am struck in a moment, you have already converted me, I will be as remarkable in my penitence, as ever I was in my wickedness, Parsons shall write books of it, and preach upon it while I am living.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: A very pretty piece of Raillery.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Raillery! by Heaven and Earth!

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no swearing, your Bead roll's long enough already, you shall shave no Sin added to it upon my account.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Sister, dear Sister lets be gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: All the Sins I ever shall commit will fall upon you, I shall run mad, stark mad, most furiously mad.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: What madder than you have been?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My former life will be thought an Anchorets to what will follow, if you refuse me. I am resolv'd to use all the ways that e're were try'd to gain a woman,— and did the world depend on me, I'de ruin all before I'de lose you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Oh fearful, I dare not hear him any longer.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Softly good Sir, he that dares make love to me must undergo a Task too hard for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Name it, there's nothing too hard for such a Lover.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I must have my weekly Tribute of Sonnet and Madrigal, full of sacred, divine, Nymph and Goddess.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And my daily offering of humble, and disconsolate billets do 〈◊〉 about the Lustre of my Beauty, the light of my Eyes, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: And this.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: I must have all former women sacrific'd to me, and he must not dare to look upon another besides me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: All all, if I had ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: All lewd Company must be deserted, and Wine abolished save three Glasses at a meal, and he must be the pattern of Vertue for the whole Town, consider now, and tremble.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: All this shall be done, I have considered, and will consider no more, nor think, nor live any longer than I shall call Eugenia mine.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Maggot, Wildfire and Priscilla.

sp.speaker: La Mag.
sp.p: Oh Heaven they are here with my Nephew, the lewdest wretch that ever breath'd this wicked air, but hold!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: What delicate man is this? He is a most surprizing creature, Heav'n! would I had not seen him!
sp.stage: Clara looking about, spies Wildfire first.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What Angel's this? I ne'r saw Beauty till this minute. She has struck me under the left Pap.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Oh my Mother.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Do you start you Baggages? were it not in the Park, I'd make you such Examples of my Rage— come along— I'll rout you out of this place. Go, go packing through St. Iames's house: I'll bring up the Rear. Follow 'em you old Gipsy, Governess. Nephew how dare you commit this outrage, this insolence upon me! Avoid my presence, and never more come near me or my house.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: This new Beauty has fir'd me, and blown me up.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Look thee, my Termagant, Masculine, He-Aunt, if thou usest me or my Cousins thus, I will scowre, and roar thee out of Soho-Square into Mark-lane again: And that will break thy heart.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: I will consider of that. Sir, if you please let me still hold the honour of your company; haste, haste.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why how now Tom!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Peace Will peace, I'll keep my time▪

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: What a Devil has Tom Wildfire taken up my Aunt?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: How now Knight Errant, have you done adventuring for Surgeons work? 'tis almost Dinner time, I long for Brimmers, did you see who went off with your Aunt! is she given to stumble? will she take a stone in her Ear?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: She comes of a good strain by the Males, but come along with me we'll make 'em a visit, what Rogues are these? [Enter Whac. Ding. and Blust. They have dog'd and star'd at us ever since we came into the Park, one looks like a tawdry Spark of the City, and the other two like Bayliffs followers.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: Sir, I understand Sir, that you are Sir William Rant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: I am, what then?

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Nay no offence, my name is Tim Whachum, Alderman Whachums Son deceased, and Alderman Maggot your Uncle in laws Nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: What would this Puppy be at?

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p:
I have seen your Person before, and admir'd you, I have seen you scower so rarely, Sir I have had a mighty Ambition for the honour of your acquaintance;
For my part Sir, I am a very mad Fellow as any wears a head, and I conceive Sir you love a mad Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: A very pleasant Rascal.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: I have heard Sir, that you delight much in drinking, whoring, scowring, beating the Watch, breaking Windows and serenading, and the like Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Was there ever such an awkard Rogue, to make a man out of love with Lewdness

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Now if there be madder Fellows about the Town than I, and my two Companions— Why we have been bound over to the Sessions three times this week. I suppose you may have heard of our roaring about Holbourn, Fetter-lane, Salisbury court, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes I have Sir, and you are most gallant, and magnanimous Fellows. Now all's out Iack Tope, we will so swinge these Rogues, Here's a Fellow of this Nuncles breeding.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Now good noble Sir if you please to honour us with your Acquaintance, I vow to Gad Sir, I shall be as proud Sir, as proud Sir as—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sir 'tis much to my Advantage, and I embrace the honour most greedily.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Well here's the finest Gentleman that ever beat a Constable, let him be whom he will; Sir, Sir I am most infinitely overjoy'd, be pleas'd to know my Friends, Godsookes, they are as gallant Fellows as ever walk'd the streets at Midnight.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Your Servant Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ding
sp.l: Your most obsequious Spaniel.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Your most humble Trout.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Trout! Pox on him for a Blockhead, is that Fellow a Trout?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Be pleas'd to know my Friend.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Sir I am no Stranger to your Worth, and Magnanimity; now noble Sir if you, and your Gang will compleat this Hononr, and sup with us to night at the Bear and Harrow, behind St. Clements, where we intend to begin our Frolick; it may be Sir you may see scowring that will not be amiss.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: We will, be sure to bespeak a good Supper.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Dam me I am overjoy'd Sir, if we joyn together we'll carry all the Town before us, your Servant sweet Sir, I'll be sure to bespeak Supper, do you love a huge Shoulder of Mutton and Oysters, and a couple of fat Capons in the first place.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Aye aye, very well: at Eight let it be.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Come Dingboy and Bluster, I am transported, I have much ado to forbear Huzzaing in the Mall.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Did you ever meet such nauseous Rascals, they will convert more than the drunken Spartan Slaves.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Whett thy Rage and let us make examples of'em, now will I teaze my haughty Aunt, and confound my foolish Uncle.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Wildf. La. Mag. Eugenia, Clara, Priscilla.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: SO, you young Rebellious Sluts, I have you safe; I'll teach you to go to the Park.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: So you do, by your own example.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: Yes, Huswife, I am experienced, and proof against temptation, by my known Vertue and Wisdom.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: And we doubt not but our unknown Vertue and Wisdom, as you call it, will defend us too.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: How now, Mrs. Milksop, are you grown pert and refractory?

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: She, she is as bad as t'other every whit.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: There's none so bad as thee, old puss. Thou filthy, toothless, wormeaten old Maid, I'll maul thee, thou Witch of Ender.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: Murther, Murther, Murther, will you throttle me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I cannot live without my pretty Creature: What charms are these? What do I feel?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh Sister, the sight of this man has ruin'd me; I never shall recover it.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Ah! art thou there faith, recover it: Why, who would put a stop to love? Give Reins to it, and let it run away with thee.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: Oh! prodigious and amazing! Did they say all this?

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.p: Yes, that they did, and ten times more: So they did, what would you have me do? They said they would throw off your Tyranny, and have no more to do with you.

sp.speaker: L, Mag.
sp.l: Oh, Heaven! Is this true? Did you say so, young Rebels?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Yes, and are resolv'd to do so. Sister, take courage, and speak thy mind.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: We were not made to be mew'd up like the Hawks in moulting time.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: We were born free, and we'll preserve that freedom; we have learn'd more Wit than to call Self-defence Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Brave mettled Girls; I grow mad in Love, and 'twill break out into a flame.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: Most amazing impudent Girls; I'll tear your eyes out.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Offer to use us thus one moment longer, and I will choose my Unkle Rant my Guardian.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And I am resolv'd to do the same.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.l: Most incredible impudence, let me come at 'em.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: I beseech your Ladyship.
sp.stage: [He takes Eugenia and Clara by the hands.
sp.l: If you be unkind as you are fair, I am for ever miserable.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Heav'n! what do I hear!

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly demand your pardon; I must confess, the disorders of my Family have transported me into an indecent passion, which a Lady of my Quality should not have exposed to a person so gallant and well-bred as your self.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Pardon me, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: But you shall find, Noble Sir, that she who can to extravagance be sensible of affronts and injuries, can with as much zeal and ardency, resent the generous favour you have loaded her with.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Madam, you make me blush with—

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: And I'll assure you, Sir, there is not a person living, who can be more grateful to a person, that obliges any person, than I shall show my self to your Noble Person.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: Hey: What Riddle's this?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Oh, Eugenia, pity me: I am ruin'd! lost to all the World!

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: But to him, and him, and only him.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: You young Rebellious Sluts, go to your Chamber, I'll come to you and discourse these matters calmly with you.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: We'll obey.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: You Cecropia, when they are in their Chamber lock the Door upon them, and keep the Key, or I will strangle thee, thou old wither'd she Baboon.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, what shall I say, what shall I do!

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: I am finely drawn in! Must I come at the Daughter by the Mother? my Conscience ne'r will serve me, that's certain: She's furious too, what the Devil shall I do to keep her off; I'll try great civility and respect to her.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Now noble Sir, I beseech you please to retire where we shall have a sitter place and opportunity more apt to express my grateful resentments.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, Madam, put not a value upon nothing; you have those charms, those graces, and that wit and beauty, that all the services of my life would be too little to express the passion which I have for you.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Sir, for me! a person that— I beseech you Sir let us retire, since I have something to impart to you, in which I willingly would not meet an interruption.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: I am yours, and only yours.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: So now they are sure, I have 'em under Lock and Key, I warrant 'em.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Humphry Maggot, Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: How now old Prisc. Where is my Lady?

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.p: With a Gentleman who came to visit her, in her Chamber; he is a stranger, I know him not. But I'll take care she shall not be surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Tell her I am here, bid 'em hasten dinner and bid the Butler bring some Hock for a whet; we in the City can't eat without several whets in a forenoon.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: I whet so often when I am there, that at last 'tis a blunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Well said Nephew, you shall see your Mistress presently.
Come, here fill a Glass. May I crave your names again, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bluster.
sp.l: Mine is Bluster.

sp.speaker: Dingboy.
sp.l: And mine is Dingboy.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Brave names for bold pleaders at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: They plead at the Bar! ha, ha, ha: They may hold up their hands there, but never hold up a breviate to point at a Judge with.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come Nephew all of us chockon, chockon, to an absent friend, ha, hum; you know— no more to be said.

sp.speaker: Whach, Blust. and Ding.
sp.l: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Well, things will come about again. Let me tell you, we shall be upon a right bottom once more.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: I am glad to hear you say so: Your Worship's a wise man.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: As wears a Head in the City.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: As wears a pair of Horns there.

sp.speaker: Sir. Humph.
sp.p: Look you, the King of France will have the greatest Fleet in the World at the Needles by February.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: But those French do so burn Houses, Churches, Barns, Men, Women and Children, that I am affraid they'll do a great deal of hurt.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Ay that's to their Enemies, but they are our Friends, Did not the Grand Lewis declare so? and that he lov'd the Church? by that brave and gallant Person, our Friend Admiral Bagnio.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Oh ay, all he does is out of kindness to us, and the sincere Friendship he has for his Kindred, I'll tell you, but we say here that, the Turks are beaten:

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Pish not a word, alas we never have any Truth, a worthy Roman Catholick whom I rely upon, told me that this same Duke of Croy lost his whole Army, and ran away by himself to the Emperour, and the Turks are now in possession of that Bridge and Town, and County of what do you call 'em, of Essex in Moldavia, and Teckley and the great Bashaw have coop'd up the German Army. Give us another Whett.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Come on.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Here's to the Turk, the Pope, and King of France, we are of one side now.

sp.speaker: Blust. & Ding.
sp.l: Come on.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: We hear all Lyes: I warrant you think Cork and Kinsale are taken, No no no, not a word; but come we shall have my Wife or some body come to interrupt us, let's retire into my smoaking Room, and we'll discourse freely of these affairs.
Oh Madam the great Tenderness I have for Ladyships honour, chills my 〈◊〉
'Tis generously spoken most noble Sir, though I am perfect mist 〈…〉 use.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh Madam the danger affrights me from the chief happiness: I wish on earth never man had such a passion as I have for her Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: So generous a passion, I cannot but think an honour to me, but I must have all go in the Platonick way henceforth. I shall make bold to call you my Strephon, and I beseech you to accept of this Ring.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Dear Madam you confound me.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Dear Sir it must not be refused, I vow'd never to part with it but as a pledge of my affection, and you being the worthiest Gentleman I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You undo me with your Favours; this may be of use as I will make it. aside. I long to have the honour of your Ladyships conversation at my house, where I may fully express the violent passion I have.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.stage: Sweet Sir! (A Flourish of Fiddles.) Ha what noise is that? some Rogues, Fidlers are come to welcome my Daughters to Town; I'll leave you for a moment Sir to see if they be safe.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What a prize would this be to a young Fellow, who wanted a keeper, who can part with such a Ring for a bare promise, which I am sure I ne'r will keep.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What is there no body in the house? hah Tom what will nothing serve you but my Family, but she is by the half blood.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Upon my honour Will. thou art in the wrong, I have no design upon thy Aunts person, but I hope to make her my instrument for stealing one of her Daughters persons.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: How, one of her Daughters!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You know I have a good clear Estate, I saw your two Cousins by accident, and am so devillishly in Love with one of 'em, that I am resolv'd if I can, even to marry her for one good night, though I were sure to be hang'd next Morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: As for the honour of my Aunt, lye with her when you will, and I'll be no more concerned than other Sparks about the Town are for their Sisters; but for my Cousins know I am in love to greater madness with one of 'em, and if yours happens to be her, I am sure that both of us shall not live.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Thou knowest Will, I am not capable of fear, if it be my fate to be in Love with the same, I can bewayl it, but can never alter.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Keep me in doubt no longer, in this case a short clearing of the matter's best.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You are in the right, and it must out, it is—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Which.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: The youngest.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My dear dear Tommy, let me hug and kiss thee; go on and prosper, I'll assist thee.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Mercy on me, who's here! are they such dear friends? What will become of me! Yet sure he's a man of Honour; he has too fast hold on me, and 'tis too late to retreat.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Oh my sweet, my honour'd Aunt, your humble servant; it is a common blockheaded trick to serenade and disturb people at midnight, I am
come to serenade you at Noon, and have ordered my dinner to come hither ' I come a house-warming.

sp.speaker: La Mag.
sp.p: Unheard of Impudence, thou most audacious Fellow, thou only blemish of our Family, did I not forbid thee my house? must thou bring Infamy where it never entred.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Look thee Aunt, if thou wilt be civil and well bred, I will kiss thy Hand, make Legs and use thee like an Aunt, but if wars must ensue, I will roar and scowre thy house so, that thou mightest lye as quietly in a besieged Town, with Limbs and Carcasses flying about thy Lodging.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Avaunt thou Devil incarnate, I'll order thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Nay then, enter my Friend Iack Tope, all my Singers, and Fiddles, and my whole Equipage De boyre.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Fear not your person, I'll protect it.

sp.speaker: La Mag.
sp.p: You shall not expose your own for it, most generous Sir, I'll order him, lewd wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Come, enter.
sp.stage: Enter Tope, Sir Williams Servants and Musicians.

sp.speaker: Lady Magg.
sp.l: Help, help, here Mr. Alderman, Mr. Maggot.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Strike up my Lads.
sp.stage: They all roar and sing and play the Tune of, Let the Souldiers rejoyce.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Come on my Boys, halloo.
Come Lady give me thy hand, dance and frisk about.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Hang the old Coxcomb, Hold, hold, hold, Mr. Maggot, Mr. Maggot.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Hump. Whac. Blust. Ding. & Butler, with other Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum.
sp.l: Hah, Gad forgive me, who are here?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh honest Alderman, nown Nuncle, i' faith we are come to roar a little with thee, and we have ordered our Dinner, we come a house-warming.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh thou tame Beast, wilt thou hear them speak? make a Warrant and send them to the Gatehouse, or Newgate.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Oh Nephew have a care of him, let's retire.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Look you Mr. Alderman, I have secured the Pass, If you will be a good towardly Unkle and take advice by me, it shall be most profound peace, and great Civility, but if you will provoke me, I'll make you spend your time very uneasily.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Oh rare, Bluster and Dingboy, here will be gallant sport, to our Hearts desire.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Oh pitiful Nincompoop, what dost fear him?

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Good Chicken, have a little patience.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Consider Madam, patience is a great vertue for a Lady of your years.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: My years, I spit at thee thou old musty Rascal, my years! Oh thou cowardly Wittal, is thy wise Nephew a coward too: I will thunder in their ears.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Nay let thee alone thou art a notable Girl.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Begone you Villains, lewd Rascals.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Strike up, out noise her!
sp.stage: They roar, and sing, and play; and leap about, and so do Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Russians, Vagabonds, Ragemuffians,
Slaves, Dogs, Scoundrels, hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Hold, hold, shall we come to Articles of Peace?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh Gallant! Oh rare sport! by Gad they are the finest Gentlemen in Christendome.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Mercy on me Nephew, did you sing and rejoyce with them.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Gad take me Sir, 'tis such a pretty Tune, flesh and blood could not forbear.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Alderman, I will swinge thee with brimmers, and make thy old mouldy Aldermanship, more drunk than ever any of the huzzaing, roaring, loyal Rascals were, who would have given up the City Charter.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I beseech you Madam, dissemble a little patience, they shall give a severe account upon my honour.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Well you have silenc'd me, and in some measure appeased me since you say you intend only a civil Musick Consort and a Dance, what would you more, I am tame.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I must have both my Cousins, it is my intention to welcome them to Town.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Out of my house, you shall be hang'd first, bring Infamy upon them, they are far enough off.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ralph secure the passes, and let no body out, send for my precise house-keeper, and instruct her as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Yes, I must do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come my Lads march and roar, I will search every Room in the house, but I will have her.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Oh thou sneaking old Fumbling Fool! get thou out thou Coward, Maggot, Infect, Nittworm.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Why Chicken, chicken, chicken.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Get thee out I say, and send for a Constable, and send them to Jail.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Come along Madam, I'll protect you, and appease them, put on a little patience, and I'll warrant you all shall be well.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Huzza my dear Rascals! Here's a day! here's a happy day! Let's hugg and kiss one another, oh my brave Midnight-boys, what a night shall we have with this rare, this excellent, this most accomplish'd Gentleman! Oh I could kiss the ground he goes upon.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Now we are leagu'd, we'll govern all the Town by night.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: We shall be stil'd the High and Mighty Princes of the night.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Shall our dull Loggerheaded Magistrates think to rule the City, with old decrepid Fools in Rug-gowns, and Furr'd Caps, no let them govern by day, but Gad take me, we honest Fellows will swagger by Night, Boys, Ha Rogues, have at them, hey.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: What shall I do? Look, my Nephew and his Companions rejoyce as much as any of 'em.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: Hold; my Uncle!

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Students of the Law, quoth he! Rakehells damn'd Rakehells, pray come and retire with me.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Will. Euge. Clara; Lady Mag. Wild. Tope. All the Musick and Servants, singing and roaring, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Madam this is to save the trouble of a Habeas Corpus, to free my Cousins from illegal Imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag. to Wild.
