sp.p: Well I will have patience Sir, but to morrow into the Country they go, and shall never come into this wicked Town, till their Husbands shall think fit to bring 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You will do well.
but I shall take care to prevent you.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: We Knights Errant, Lady, are bound by our noble order to succour distressed Damsels, and free them from enchanted Castles, and to mall Gyants, and more fell creatures, your Viragos Madam, your Viragos, hah.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now my pretty sweet Cousins, let me have the honour to entertain you with Musick, as your welcome to Town, this is a Forenoon Serenade.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Sir 'tis a favour we must think our selves obliged for, after Bag-pipers, blind Harpers, and Country old-fashion'd Virginal Masters.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And which is worse than all, the full cry of a country Cathedral.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Very well, very well Baggages, I'll order you.
Let 'em begin Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now you are my good Aunt, I love and honour you, now I have brought you to reason, come Gentlemen begin.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Where's my Alderman? my dear Alderman? I must have him here, I will fetch him in.
sp.stage: Re-enter with the Alderman Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: If you do not contrive suddenly, to get your Aunt out of the way for a moment, that I may speak to my Mistress, I am utterly ruin'd. I'll tell you the Reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: I warrant you, after the dance expect I have a way.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Tis admirable Musick.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And well performed.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: I charge you Nephew, avoid this Company, as you would Bears or Tygers.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Avoid 'em, no I'll hang first, good Nuncle, I intend to throw off your Yoke immediately, our scowring cannot be long conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Pox I hate these melancholy, foolish, love Madrigals, with damn'd imitation of the Italians quavering and division, one Jolly drinking Song, is worth a thousand, you shall let me have my Frolick, sing me a Chauson de boire. A drinking Song. Hah this is right, I Gad there's some mettal in this, a Pox of Phillis and Cloris, this is my Frolick.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Tis very well Iack, now strike up for a Dance, and by that time Dinner will enter.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Come along my Lads, hem, hem, now Madam you shall see who's old, I will be Master of the Revels, and couple ye, here Alderman you shall dance with my Lady, no parting Man and Wife, ne'r dispute, Gad it shall be so: Here Will here's a Lady for you.
sp.stage: He gives him Eugenia. gives him Clara.
sp.p: Tom Wildfire here's a Lady for you.
And for my self, I have a pretty young Jade in my Eye, here come out, come I say, I'll seague thee away i'faith, strike up, strike up, men of Rosin, Old! Gad take me, I'll see who's old now.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Why thou art a Youth, a Lad Iack in thy prime.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh thou old fumbling cowardly Fellow to bear all this, I'll order thee, Old Numps.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Gad forgive me, what a sad life shall I live with? Chicken.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Strike up again.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: What a Pox they make nothing of me, but I'll make something of my self, they shall find.
sp.stage: They dance, Whacum jumps and struts, and dances awkardly with them.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now Tom watch, my Lady will follow me: Madam I beg the Honour of one word in the next Room.
sp.stage: [Sir Will. draws Eug: to the next Room.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will if it be only to tease my Mother.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Come my little Rogue, let us retire, Alderman I will lye with thy Maid, and make thee drunk, and that will be a good days work.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Go you are a Wag, i' faith you are.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh Impudence! My vile Nephew run away with my Daughter, along with me old Fool, with your Nephew and his Friends, come, come.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Well Chicken well, come along Nephew and Students.
sp.stage: Exeunt Lady, Sir Humphry, Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam your opportunities are so few, and like to be fewer, that it were an unpardonable sin to let one slip, your mother intends to send you into the Country by violence to morrow morning, you see Madam I dare not address to you before her.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Sir you oblige me in this notice, but my Sister and we will prevent it.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: I humbly beg the honour of serving you, never man had such a passion as you have raised in me, a flame will ruine and destroy me, your Person nothing can deserve, but my Estate is plentiful without incumbrance.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, that I am so free with you, you are a wild man of the Town, and I would as soon commit my self to the Mercy of the Sea, in a storm, as into your Hands.

sp.speaker: Wild
sp.p: I should not presume to be thus daring to mention love, at first encounter, but that the difficulty is like to be so great of seeing you; and I must let you know it, if you refuse me, I must perish, and I dare prophesy you'll be unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Are you at that sport, this shall to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: '●is better to be unfortunate than foolish.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Whatever I have been, the world shall never make me wild again unless your scorn should make me desperate, and then what fury it may drive 〈◊〉 to I know not.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Nor have I reason to be concern'd, 'twill be no fault of mine. Why does the custom of our foolish Sex oblige us to lying, I see no prospect of any thing but ruine; I am resolv'd never to joyn my self to Lewdness, and yet his Person charms me into madness, oh misfortune!

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: I shall wish all the world except your self, on fire! if you despise me.
sp.l: Curse on this Rascal, I could willingly cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Madam your most obedient Servant. Sir under the Rose she is my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Damnation on this Loggerhead.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: I'll tell you in your ear her Father has made a match for me and her, and I am to give her Mother 5000l. for her, ha, hum.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Ay but you are a man of honour, to tell you truth I am for the Eldest, she loves a mad Fellow like me.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Now Madam consider, your Father in Law has made a match, and your Mother has sold you for 5000l. to this Puppy, but he says he is for the Eldest, she loves a mad Fellow like him.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Sir, let me tell you, 'tis somewhat uncivil to tell words that I spoke under the Rose, I trusted to the Faith of a gallant Scowrer.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Thou art a mighty thick skull'd Coxcomb, and I have a great Temptation to tweak thee by the Nose.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Gad save me he is a very gallant Gentleman.
sp.stage: Enter L. Maggot haling in Eugenia by the Hand, Sir Will. and Pris. follows.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh outragious Impudence! You steal one Daughter out of my presence, and another makes love to her I left, I'll blow up the house before I'll bear this.

sp.speaker: Wildf. spying my Lady.
sp.p: Prithee come on your self, you sneaking City wit and make love to your Mistress your self, do you think to put me upon it.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: What a Devil do's he mean.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You are the bashfullest Fop, I ever saw, prithee stand up, hold up your head, and speak your mind. Oh Madam I humbly kiss your Ladyships hands, your Kinsman here has been putting me upon saying fine things for him.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: I am overjoy'd to find you the same man of honour I thought you, but my Nephew Sir William—

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Madam, I never keep him Company.
sp.stage: Enter Tope, Alderman, Bluster and Dingboy.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Come on my Lads, all you that are not given to mornings draughts rejoyce, enter Dinner in state, come in Fiddles, I am Sewer and will march in the head of it. Enter Venison, Turbott, Calvert Salmon and the rest; and let the lusty Bearers of the swinging Hamper come, do you Friends bring up the Rear.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Well I will dissemble, till I get these Rascals out of my house.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Oh my dear Rogue here will be sport; here will be a glorious day! Bluster and Dingboy that old Gentleman is a very pretty Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Now strike up and march along Boys.
sp.stage: They march out with Dinner, singing and roaring, and old Tope in the head of them.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Eugenia, Clara, in their Chamber.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: HERE will be fine work to day, the Alderman will by typsy'd as he calls it, my Lady-mother will be outragious; but it seems she intends us for the Country to morrow.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And has sold me for 5000l. to the Aldermans most impertinent Nephew.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: And no doubt has made as good a bargain for me, but we will defeat her Ladiship: And for that end I withdrew with thee to consult about our Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I have no prospect of Deliverance, let me stay here, or go into the Country, I must be for ever miserable; I am in love to madness, to utter madness.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: No sure it cannot be, did not I hear a certain young Lady say, she would not fall in love with a wild man of the Town, tho he could joynture her with the East Indies.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Oh Eugenia! 'tis against my will, I sooner would have chosen to have been blasted with Lightning: Love struck as fiercely through my heart, and as little could I resist it: But prithee do not triumph over my Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: Misfortune: why Loves the greatest blessing upon Earth, Life is nothing but a Shadow, Love is the Substance: Methinks I should be nothing but a moving clod without it: Besides he loves thee as furiously too, what wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Not him of all the world.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: Nor I the other, till I see a full Reformation in his Life, and Manners; If they think us worth that, they will soon shew the change, if they do not, sure we shall have the sense to think them not worthy of us.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: These wild young men, like Tinder soon take Fire, and as soon 'tis out again; they'll never change, nor has Love left me any sence but of my Misery—

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: Poor Clara! What dost weep? poor Girl, thou art a Maudlin Lover; This comes of Romances: I could never wean thee from 'em, for my part I am resolv'd to keep up my Spirit, come what will.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Prithee do not laugh at me, to be a Jest is the vilest, and most miserable of Conditions.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p:
And that thou wilt deserve, ifthou wilt not do any thing towards thy own Freedom, thou art like those unreasonable craven Fellows that would do nothing towards the Deliverance of England, and yet would have all the
benefit of the change, nay would keep those that did, out of the Government.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Prithee don't draw a Simile upon me, I am resolv'd to do any thing Reason or Honour will allow.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: In the first place, you resolve to choose my Uncle Rant your Guardian.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: Secondly to be rul'd by him, he is a just, vertuous and honourable man, and of great Humanity.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I will wholly resign my self to him.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: Thirdly and lastly, thou wilt take the first opportunity of honourably, and prudently running away.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Thy hand upon't.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Done.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now let my brain work, what has our Jaylor been at the Door?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Twas very silently.
sp.stage: Pris. unlocks the Door, and lets in Whachum.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Are you there old Mrs Turnkey?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Yes, and you are like to be there, I can tell you, while I am so.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Ladies I am your most humble Footstool to command, we have had a smart bout on't with these Gallants, to say the Truth on't, they are as fine Gentlemen as e're the Sun shin'd on.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But how came you to enter here, sweet Sir?

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Sweet Sir! good. aside. By your Lady Mothers Command dear sweet Madam, I have an affair to communicate to you, Madam Eugenia! But it must be in private, your Ear sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: You need not whisper, I'll into the Closet.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Now Madam, Cozen, if I may be so bold, but I hope to be nearer of Kin to you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What you have bought my Sister for 5000l. I hear?

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Yes that I have of your Lady Mother, but as Gad save me I think my Lady's too dear, she is a very Iew, she has no Conscience, and to tell you the Truth Madam, as I am an honest man, betwixt you and I, I don't like the bargain, I had rather buy you Gold to Silver.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: To tell you Truth, I don't like that bargain.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: You are a Wag Madam, but I am for your aery, brisk, gay, wild, young Filly, such as you are, there's your Lady for my Money; and if you will be rul'd by me, we'll save the 5000l. and mump my Lady, Faith what say you? hah hum.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My Lady shall have no 5000l. there I'll be rul'd by you.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Sweet Madam, I kiss your hands, Come, come, I know your heart, as well as if I were in you, as the saying is, come you love a brave mad Fellow, such as I am, Sniggs, I am one of the maddest Fellows about the Town, I sing, roar, serenade, bluster, break Windows, demolish Bawdy-houses, beat Bawds, scower the Streets, and the like, as well as any he that swaggers in the Town, ha Lady.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: A very pretty ingenious Fellow.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Ay Madam, I am all Frolick, how many Knockers of Doors do you think I have at home now, that I twisted off when I scower'd, guess now:

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Tis impossible to guess.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Why above two Hundred, ha hum, is not that very well? O my Conscience this morning I beat 20 Higling women! spread their Butter about the Kennel, broke all their Eggs, let their sucking Pigs loose, flung down all the Peds with Pippins about the streets, scower'd like Lightning, and kick'd fellows like Thunder, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Ay wast not, ha, ha, ha; I wip'd out all the Milk scores at the Doors, nay I went about serenading with six Fidlers in a Dung-cart. Ha, ha, there was a Frolick, ha, ha, there's a mad fellow for you, and you talk of a mad Fellow; 'tis true Sir William and his Companions are pretty men, very pretty men: But I wou'd you saw me scower.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You a mad Fellow, and talk of scowring! why don't you break open the door, and beat our old sawcy Governess for locking us up?

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Ha, now you put me in mind of it, I vow and swear I'll do't presently, for I love and honour you, and if you don't look upon me, I shall hang my self.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: No no but you are in a pretty fair way for another to do it for you.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Well Madam, but I'll show you what a mad Fellow I am, this Night I'll scower Soho Square, I gad you shall see such scowring, 'twill rejoyce your heart.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Can you drink hard?

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Oh bloodily, if you could but see me at the Popes-head, no merry gang can be without me, there I laugh, and roar, and sing and am exceeding witty, the purest Company! never stir, they swear I have more wit than any of the Poets.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: That may very well be by the late Plays I have read, but all this while we are Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Odsookers that's true. Here where are you, old damn'd old she Jaylour? I'll break open the door.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: What means this uproar.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Come on Mrs. Tawdry? Old Trigrimate? I will make thy dry bones rattle within the old tan'd Hide of thee; I'll swinge thee, Mother Damnable! what dost thou lock up these pretty Ladies, Drab, Pole-cat.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Help, help, Murther, murther,
sp.stage: He hales and turns her about, and kicks her, she flyes at him and scratches him.
sp.l: oh you young Impudent Fellow,
I'll tear out your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Why how now Hag! dost thou scratch?
sp.p: Old Puss, thou art grown into a Cat already, and shortly wilt take the degree of a Witch upon thee, have at thee, do you provoke me you damn'd Puss?

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: Murther, murther, murther.
sp.stage: He beats her and she scratches him.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Heav'n and Earth! What outrage is this? Some trick of yours, you wicked Sluts.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Oh she has scratch'd and blooded me all over, for ought I know, I may lose the use of my Face.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: O Madam he has call'd me filthy names, abus'd and beat and kick'd me, for locking these pert unruly Creatures up.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Death you young Rascal! dare you abuse my faithful Servant for obliging me? you stupid Coxcomb, for keeping your Mistress from running away from that ugly Phiz of thine; get thee out of my house, I'll order thee for a City Puppy, be gone, be gone.
sp.stage: She pummels him with her Fan, and Fist as he runs

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Hold hold, hold— was ever such a Vixen? hold!

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Come Baggages you were of the party, come come, I'll endure these things no longer.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Nor we neither.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Nor will we be for a Country Journy to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Will not?

sp.speaker: Eug. & Clara.
sp.l: No, will not.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: The World, this House, and my Brains, are turn'd topsy turvy. The plagues of this one day alone are able to distract me: Priscilla, thou hast done well, haste and lock 'em up again, I'll try a pluck with ye.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: I warrant 'em, I'll keep them safe.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Let's into our Closet and consult, we will escape before our Country Journey yet.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: O Will, this Cousin of thine has so bewitch'd me, that I begin to hate lewdness already.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Faith, I have not such a relish for it, methinks, as I have had; but not a word to old Tope.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: When he finds us out, the Rogue will play the Tyrant most insolently.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: He'll be worse to us two than Doll Common to Face and Subtile▪ But something must be done to deliver these pretty Rogues; to morrow, at Nine in the Morning, is short warning.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Manage matters so, that we may appear Enemies when your Aunt comes to us; and that, with what I have already protested, will beget such confidence of me, that I'll undertake to secure her early in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I have laid a design, which I hopè will take, to free them; but if Stratagem will not do't, Force shall.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: That may be dangerous, and hinder us for ever. Here she is, I assure you, Sir—
You shall not carry this off, I pass'd my word to protect your Aunt, and I shall require a strict account of this affront you have put upon her.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What a Devil! Are you concern'd for the honour of my Aunt? What, do you lye with her?

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: What say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, hold; out thou filthy Fellow: Thou foul-mouth'd Brute: Thou very Spirit of Lewdness and Scandal: Shall I, who am most notorious for Vertue and Prudence to the whole Town, be blasted by thy Contagious breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Far be it from me to think such a thing; but I might justly, for your sake, suspect his Vanity.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: He is a Man of Honour, and a Worthy Gentleman; I would I cou'd say that of thee. But, sweet Mr. Wildfire, if you should engage your felt in a Quarrel for me, I should never enjoy my self while I lived.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Madam, I'll not engage with him; what, mine own Aunt! My dear aunt! I love and honour thee.

sp.speaker: L Mag.
sp.p: Love and Honour thee, quoth he! Pray Love and Honour me, and 〈◊〉 get out of my House.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I will; but by this hand I will Serenade and Scowre thee most confoundedly.

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: Sir, I must have your word not to Quarrel: You see what his lewd heart is apt to suggest, upon your beginning One, I shall suffer in my untainced Reputation, besides the exposing your dear person, will endanger my life.

sp.speaker: Vildf.
sp.p: You are infinitely gracious.
sp.stage: Enter Tope leading the Alderman, drunk.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Oh Madam are you there, here is your Alderman safe and sound, I deliver him to you, pray give me a note under your hand for the Receipt of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: I fack Mr. Tope you are a Wag, ay I fack a very Wag.

sp.speaker: Tope
sp.p: I could make as pretty a Magistrate of him, if I had but the breeding of him as ever slept upon a Bench yet, Old, Madam! Iack Tope old, Madam! hah.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Oh Chicken, Chicken! my dear Chicken! I'll so mouse thee.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Confusion of Babel! what has this day produc'd? I shall run mad, mad, staring mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Why Chicken! I say, Chicken.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Why Buzzard, I say Buzzard, get you gone you drunken Owl.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Nay Alderman, what are you a Flincher? does the Hen crow? come t'other Brimmer.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Out on thee old Satan! thou vile Tempter! would'st thou most wickedly seduce a man from the Loyalty, and Obedience he owes to his lawful Soveraign wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: One brimmer dear Chicken, it shall be thy health, never stir I'll buss thee my pretty Chicken, I'll buss thee.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Buss me, oh Insolence! get you out, I say, be gone, ha, what dare you stay?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Sweet Chicken, now do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: How! Is it come to this? Nay then I'll make you go, do you Rebel?
sp.stage: [She strikes him with her Fan, and thrusts him out by the Nape of the Neck, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Good, good, ha ha, good, hey brave Matrimony! oh rare Matrimony! Oh gallant Matrimony! Most comfortable Matrimony! Oh delicate Matrimony! Oh sweet Matrimony! Oh heavenly Matrimony! Where are you Flinchers? I have been fain to carry on the work of the day; you have been as dull as a couple of old gelt Mastisses.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Why, Iack, thou art the Hero of the Age.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: There's not a Youth in Town comes near thee.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Hem, hem; Old said ye; hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Sir, here's a Letter from your Father, came just now by the Post.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Some wise advice again, I warrant; but how does my House-keeper, and the damn'd Governess agree?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The Old Dragon swallows Sack as greedily as a Essex Calf sucks Milk. She was called away once, but we are safe now, and hope to bring her to reason.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: How are the rest of the Family?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: All, every one, as drunk as ever you were Sir, except two Maids of my Ladies, Whachum and his two Friends are slipt away; but Whachum had beaten the Governess, and she scratch'd him most wickedly before he went.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Go about thy business.
Now what says Daddy?
sp.stage: Sir William goes to the Candle and reads.
sp.p: Reads. I cannot tell how to express the sorrow I conceive for your obstinate persevering in such lewd courses— Pish, the old stuff over and over, I'll sacrifice thee to the flame: 'Tis better than being put under Pye-crust. [He sets it on fire. Hold, hold! What a Devil's here?
sp.stage: Reads. I have ordered five hundred pound, which— He puts it out again.
sp.l: Gad I had made fine work on't indeed!
sp.stage: Which is to be paid to my Banker in Lumbard-street, for some Uses of mine not to be dispenc'd with, and therefore am out of Money at this time.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: This is pleasant Iack, it goes to't now.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: As sure as ever Martyr did in Smithfield.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Paid away, quoth he? paid to a Banker? Oh plague of a Banker, go on, go on, burn in the Devils name,
sp.stage: He sets it on fire again.
sp.l: Ha! Death and Hell! what's this? I am undone, no 'tis legible.
sp.stage: Puts it out again very hastily.
sp.p: Reads. Yet I have sent you a bill for 25●● to receive, which you will find at the bottom of my Letter. Ounds I am undone, hold, hold, O 'tis legible, Faith 'twas a narrow scape, 'twas just a going. He puts it out again hastily. This won't do, but thou art a good Dad, 'tis a pretty Stop Gap faith Lads, we'll have Dads health in a brimmer.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: In two Will, at least.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Thou art resolv'd to be a finisht piece.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: I hate Owl-light, I would either be dead sober or dead drunk. I hate to have one keep a pother, to make me gamesome for another.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Thou scorn'st to be an odious Trimmer in drink. But prithee Iack, what if we three should resolve once, to go to bed sober in a Frolick.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Faith Iack, let us e'en try how it will agree with us.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: What a Pox do you mean? are you mad? stark mad? I go to bed sober! what to hear Chimes, Bell-men, and tell Clocks all night, and be Flea-bitten like a Nurse-Maid? I think the Devil's in you, what is this Fool in Love too?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Ten times more than I.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p:
Why you brace of Baboons! what melancholy dull Puppies does Love make of Fellows? A Pox of your Love. Love! 'tis a silly boyish Disease,
and should never come after the Chicken pox, and Kib'd heels.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag
sp.p: Now Sir William, I hope you will be so civil to leave my House, and take that old Sinner with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, and that young Sinner too.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Old sinner! Gad as good a sinner as your self.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: I must secure him for fear of a Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Quarrel! No no, there shall be no quarrel; but we will have him along with us.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: There is no remedy, but your Ladyship shall hear from me the first minute I can get loose from them, or free from their dogging.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: I shall either be at home, sweet Sir, or at my Lady Wagtayles, at Ombre, within two doors.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: This noble present of yours be the Token.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Farewel my most dearly beloved and highly honoured Aunt.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: for serenading and scowering have at you▪ sweet young Lady

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Your most humble Servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Your most obliged humble Servant, dear Sir! Oh he is the sweetest person, the most charming Creature: but for the other two, vengeance lig● on them; they have put me by the happiest opportunity.
sp.stage: Enter Ralph and Sir Williams House-keeper Abigal, leading in Priscilla drunk.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Dear Cousin! I am heartily glad do'e see of your acquaintance, 'tis pure ●ack, one cup more and then I stop, I would not be disguised for the world.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Here sweet Madam, drink it off, it makes you look so lovely in my Eyes, I am ten times more enamour'd.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: You are very obliging, sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Abigal.
sp.p: He will be an excellent Match, my Master has given him his Life in a brave Farm.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Alas, I marry! Nay not but I must confess, he is a pretty young man, &c.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Humph, sweet Madam, t'other Cup I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, well, you havea strange way with you.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Oh let me kiss those pretty eyes!

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: Go get you gone you good natur'd Toad.

sp.speaker: Abigal.
sp.p: But Cozen my master is resolv'd to increase your Fortune, that you shall live like a Gentlewoman, and he intends you 1000l.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.p: Truly he is a sine Gentleman, and if I can with a safe Conscience, well, no more to be said.

sp.speaker: Abig
sp.l: I'll send you a divine.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: No no, I can drink no more.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I'll send you a Divine to satisfie your Conscience.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.l: No, not a drop more, good night, good night.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: Do you see now you simple Fellow, you have over-drunk her, and made her commit a great sin, and spoyl'd all.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p:
Old Nab thou art a Fool, I will pick her Pocket of the Key, and release
the Ladies, and leave them to their own Discretion: Ha this must be it.
sp.stage: [He picks the Key out of her Pocket

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Go go quickly, and I'll hasten home.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: And I to the Bear and Harrow after my master, where I doubt not but I shall venture a broken head at least.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Rant, Father to Sir William, and his man Jasper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: What's the matter in this house? The Porter's drunk, and can't speak, no body to be seen about the house? Nothing but Chairs, Stools, Tables flung about, and every corner strew'd over with empty Bottles, I wish the house is not rob'd.

sp.speaker: Iasper.
sp.l: Here's an old Gentlewoman in her Cups.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: How, what confusion has been here? Some very extraordinary accident has been in this House, this is the Dragon employ'd to watch my Nieces. Go out and bring what Servants you can muster, Butler, under Butler, and Grooms, let us see if any one in the Family can speak.

sp.speaker: Iasper.
sp.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: This looks as if my Son, and all his lewd Companions, had been here. My Sister's not at home, her Doors open, no body to give account of her, or her Husband, that I could see, what all drunk? where's my Lady?
sp.stage: Enter Butler and 4 or 5 Servants drunk and staggering; after them Mr. Rants Servant with my Ladies maid, Lettice.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: We have been drinking, Helter Skelter, Faith!

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Sir William Rant's the finest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.l: Oh the bravest Gentleman! and his men the bravest Drinkers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: I thought none, but my profligate Son could have made such disorder and confusion any where.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: A most brave Gallant! No more to be said.

sp.speaker: Mr Rant.
sp.l: Is there not one in the Family can speak?

sp.speaker: Iasper.
sp.p: Yes here's a young Gentlewoman pretty sober, but there are 8 or 10 men and boys drunk, roaring under Benches and upon the Floor, the house looks like a Field after a Battle, strew'd with Bodies.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Sweet-heart! what's the cause of all this?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Sir William Rant and his Companions came in here, roaring and singing with Fiddles at Noon, entertain'd us with Musick, very fine indeed, and we had a Dance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Heaven! there is no hopes of Amendment.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: At last march'd in a noble Dinner, and great Hampers of all sorts of wine, and there has been nothing but Roaring, and Drinking ever since, till just now. My Lady laid my master drunk upon the Bed, but he has made his escape. My Lady has been almost distracted.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Fly fly, my Lady will be outragious.

sp.speaker: La. Mag
sp.l: Oh Heaven and Earth! what's here?
What an image of Hell has this house been to day? Who's here my Brother?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: Madam I knew I should surprise you, my coming to Town was very unexpected, and sudden.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p:
You find me Sir, in amazement and confusion, and I am troubled
that I must tell you, your wild Son after I had warn'd him my house, broke open my Doors, roar'd and swagger'd, and debauch'd all my Family.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, I heard something before, and am infinitely sorry, his perseverance in this wicked life will break my heart, it cannot hold long.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh Horrour, Horrour! Priscilla drunk too! Huswife! Huswife! speak.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: I will drink no more, I tell you, I am sleepy.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Mercy on me, where are my Daughters? They are flown, they are flown. Ha how came they here?
sp.stage: Enter Eug Clara. Eug. kneels to Mr. Rant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: O dear pretty Ladies! your humble Servant, bless you my sweet God-daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: How now Baggages, how came you out?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: A thousand welcomes to you most honour'd Uncle.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: You never could have arrived so seasonably.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: What mean my pretty Nieces?

sp.speaker: L. Mag.
sp.p: I shall be distracted, ruin'd. O this fatal day! I am sorry, Sir, you must be witness of the further confusion in our Family; these wicked young Sluts have rebell'd against me, that I am forc't to lock 'em up.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: We do rebel against the Locking up.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And will dye before we will endure it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And therefore are both resolved to choose you our Guardian: And never to disobey you, who we know to be a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: How they astonish me! All this mischief has your Son caus'd: Oh I shall grow mad.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant,
sp.p: Oh that Son lies heavy on me. My pretty Nieces, I should be glad to serve you, for your own sakes, and for my dear Brothers sake, tho by the second venter, he was a brave, and worthyman, an ornament of our Family. But I must by no means encourage disobedience to a Parent, or rob a mother of her Daughters.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I beseech you give us leave to state our Case to you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: And if you think we have not reason—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: We will do whatever you determine with us.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: But if you will not protect us from the most horrible Cruelty imaginable, some body else must.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: We'll bear all Torments, rather than the Usage we have met with from a mother.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Oh Impudence! I'll beat their teeth out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: Hold Madam, no such correction, let's discourse this matter in the drawing-room Nieces, a little Coolness and kind Usage shall bring 'em into a good Temper, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Heaven preserve my Sences, I have scarce any left.

div.stage: SCENE the Bear and Harrow behind St. Claments Church, The Bar-boy ringing.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum.
sp.p: I am almost typsy'd but I must have one Half-Flask with my Attorny who is here, as his Clerk says.

sp.speaker: Bar-boy rings.
sp.p: Very welcome Gentlemen, here Ralph, George, Humphry, speak here.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum.
sp.l: Is Mr. Split-cause the Attorny here.

sp.speaker: Bar-boy.
sp.l: Yes Sir, shew the Half-Moon there.
Speak there, they have rung thrice in the Bear.

sp.speaker: Drawers.
sp.l: Anon, anon Sir. Anon, anon Sir.
sp.stage: Enter Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy, and 3 Footmen of Whachums.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Anon you Dogs, can't you hear? I'll try if you have Ears, I'll lug ye.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Come Rogues, cant you feel, if you can't hear.
sp.stage: They lug 'em by the Ears, & beat & kick them.

sp.speaker: Dingb.
sp.l: Dance ye Dogs, we'll make you frisk.

sp.speaker: Drawers.
sp.l: Murther! murther.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Ye Rogues, I'll teach you to wait, you Spaniels! you Curs.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Gentlemen what's the matter? Why do you abuse and beat my Drawers.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Nay then, Rogue, lay hold on him Footmen.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Gentlemen what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: To swinge you most exceedingly, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: To learn you the reverence due to a Gentleman, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Hold him sast, first let's demolish;
sp.p: Now as a Correction of greater Dignity to your Person, you shall be toss'd in a Blanket, and not kick'd, and we'll toss fair.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Hold, hold Gentlemen for Mercies sake, and I will do any thing in the world.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: We'll let him go on his good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: This must be Sir W. Rant, and his Company, most certainly.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Look you Puppy, we intend to swagger, roar, and drink bloodily, and domineer in the House by our selves.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I beseech you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Dam me, what do you mutter?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: No Sir, not I in the least, do your pleasure Sir: Plague on 'em they'll undo my House.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: You harbour a Company of Tradesmen, who should be at home, minding of their Callings, and solacing their Wives.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Attornies, and Students, and Clarks; I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Grave men and men of business drink, and come to Taverns!

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: It must not be, I will reform these Exorbitances, and you shall find us Drunkards do more good than all the Formal, Hypocritical, Nonsensical Magistrates. Fetch us a Flask, and let it be better than our last, as thou tendrest any member about thee, and if thou valuest thy late Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: We will drink some Bumpers, at thy late Bar, and then begin our Frolicks.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: A Devil of your Frollicks, my house had as good be visited by the Plague, as such Customers.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Oh that Sir William were here, he'd be in love with us. Come fill round you Rascal, What Glasses are these? fit for Quakers, Brownists, or Fifth-Monarchy men, take one your self, now altogether give fire; now to our work.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Well there's no resisting, this same Sir William and his damn'd Company have beaten half the Town.
sp.stage: Exeunt Whach. Blust. Ding. and Footmen.
Enter Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy, and Footmen, beating a Company of Tradesmen before 'em, who cry, Fly fly, murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Get you out you Scoundrels, men of Callings, Knaves of business, must you be swilling at a Tavern, and neglect your several and respective cozening Vocations?

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.p: You Rogues must your poor Wives want your Loggerheads at home, and you be here idling and spending their Money.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.p: Go ye Scot and Lot Knaves that cheat the Parish, and the poor when you come to Offices.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Do you mutter, avaunt ye what d'ee lacks; And impudent Duns, be gone. Don't I do it rarely? Come to the next Room.
sp.stage: They beat 'em soundly, who cry, Fly, fly, murther, murther.
Enter Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy, &c. beating the Company, Attorneys, Clerks, and a Parson.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: You idle drunken Puppies, we'll swinge you for your Debauchery, and Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Attor.
sp.l: What's this? I'll bring my Quare fremuerunt; the Law's my Buckler.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: You Scoundrels stay at home, and make cozening bills for your Clients.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Practice Court-hand, you lazy drunken Rascals.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: And never be out at a Knavish Trickum de Lege.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Out ye Rogues, I'll shew you the Law

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.l: Here's one Rogue still hidden in a Closet.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Mercy upon me, my Uncle.
sp.stage: [Whac. and he start at sight of one another.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.l: Oh lack, Oh lack my Nephew! Students of the Law! quoth he?

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: What a Pox, all must out; 'tis too late to go back: Get you home old Fellow, interrupt not our pleasures. Get you gone and comfort my Lady if you can; march, march, I say.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Prodigious! Amazing!

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: March, march, or I will swinge you extreamly.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Murther! murther! Students of the Law!

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: This was bravely done, Squire.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Admirably perform'd.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Aye wast not? come let's in, Sir William will be here soon.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but the Master and Drawers.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: These are rare Customers, they have a huge Supper, but what a Pox all I get by 'em.
sp.stage: Enter Sir William, Tope, Wild. Ralph, & Footmen.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hey what has been to do here? The Puppies have been at work already, ' who's here? what Company have you in your House?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Company, Sir? but one, who have beat all the rest out of my house, blooded all my Drawers, pull'd down my Bar and swing'd me off, Company for the Devil: Sir William Rant and his wicked Crew, I ne're saw 'em before, and the Devil take 'em before I see 'em again.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Have they a good Supper?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: A huge one.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: We'll sup with 'em, these are the Rogues that laugh.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Gentlemen, as you love your lives—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Peace Fool, we'll govern your House a little better, come on Friends, let's make 'em a civil visit by the way of Kick and Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: So now I shall have Murther in my House:
sp.stage: Exeunt Sir William, Wildfire, Tope, Ralph and Footmen.
Enter Whachum, Bluster, Dingboy and Servants in a Room.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: This beating of Nuncle, was the gallantest action.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Ay what care I.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: He could not have been more amazed, if he had seen a Ghost.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Oh Sir William and Gentlemen, your most humble Servant, oh if you had come sooner you had seen such Scowring.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: You scowre, you are meer novices, we'll teach ye how to scowre.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Thank you sweet Sir Will. we shall be glad to learn, I vow to Gad Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why look you Gentlemen, you city Puppies, you impertinent conceited Rascals! Go and swagger at Puddle-dock, but do you think we will suffer such awkard sneaking Coxcombs, to wench, drink, and scower, to usurp the Sins of Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: We will tweak you by the Noses most excessively,
sp.stage: [They tweak Whac. by the Nose and kick and cudgel them.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Kick you most plentifully.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: And cudgel you most extravagantly.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: I'll take my Oath 'tis mighty well, Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come Insects, we will correct your Impudence. Such as you turn Gentlemen, when you are intended for Pleaders of the Law.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Rarely! Admirably well done!
sp.stage: [Sir Will. and his Company tweak, and lead 'em about by the Noses, they laugh all the while.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: They tweak damnably hard though.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: They do not consider the Tenderness of my Bolt-Sprit.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Get you home Rogues? study the Law, and put cases over a pot of Ale in your Chambers.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Must such paltry Fellows as you swagger in Taverns, go and pester Ale-houses.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Incomparable! by my Sword, they are the finest Gentlemen in Europe.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Dam me Squire I don't like this.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Gad they kick with Iron toes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: What do you take me to be in Jest?

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Ay ay, why Sir are you not?

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: We'll put you out of doubt of that presently.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Our you Rascals, must you be taken for us? to our utter Scandal,
Get you out.
sp.stage: They beat 'em out, Blust. & Ding. roar all the time and huff: Whac. runs as fast as he can, as they come at the Door, the Constable with the Watchmen & Tradesmen who were beaten enter, & beat them back into the house, Sir Will. & his Company beat all out.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Ye damn'd dull imitating Dogs, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Whac
sp.l: Why Sir William, Sir William, hold hold.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: What a Devil do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Do not provoke me any further.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Provoke? Damn thee out, beat 'em out.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: What will become of the Supper?
Come turn out, hang the Supper.
Now Ralph here's Honour to be gotten.
Broken Heads.
Fall on.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Will. Rant, Tope, Wildf. Ralph, Footmen and Musicians.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Hasten the Serenade, the Morning comes on apace, 'tis almost three.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: People will be awake, and then we shall lose the great end
Serenading and Scowering, which is disturbing of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Now guilty Wretches in their frighted sleeps,
Start with the Terrour of their crying sins:
Now the mean, busy, undermining Knave,
The treacherous Statesman who betrays his Prince,
And Country, rolls, and turns himself about,
The Horror of his crimes admits no rest.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: What a Devil is the Fellow mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: The tender Virgins in soft Slumbers dream,
With Innocence of all the Toys of Love;
When Nature free, and undisguis'd by Art,
The Genuine Dictates of the mind pursues,
And they are pleased with imitated Joy.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: What's the matter man, art thou in a Fit?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p:
Thou art mad Will, that's most certain. but thou hast laid down a true Doctrine, that women always dissemble, but when they are asleep: But
what a Devil do you mean? if you don't begin your Musick, Gad take me, I will roar most bloodily by my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why don't the Poets always make a man, if he be damnably in Love, in any great Passion, in Haste, or a Dying, to be full of Similes and long Descriptions?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: And because they are Coxcombs, wilt thou be one?

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: I have extraordinary business in haste, at Three in the Morning, and I must stop till I make a Poetical Description.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: For example. The thirsty Drunkard dreams of Bottle Ale,
Or sucking a whole Barrel from the Tap;
The Oyly Cookmaid stretches now, and yawns,
And calls on Dick the Plowman in her Sleep,
Who snores with Fumes from Suffolk Cheese and Bacon:
Green-sickness Maids now dream of Clay and Lime.
sp.p: Now what a Devil's this to my business if they do? either begin your serenade, or I will roar and wake your Mistriss with my shrill melodious Pipe.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: A ganders Pipe has much more Musick in't.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Thou sing! she will take it for braying: but come on, Ralph is the Constables trap set to secure that passage.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Yes it is, they must come this way, 'tis directly from their Guard.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Come then begin.
sp.stage: A window opens. Symphonies. Eugenia and Clara appear.
sp.p: Hold, the young Ladies window opens, give me the cleft stick, Ralph. Now Tom for our Billets, good luck go with them, they are they, I see now.
sp.l: Ladies take these Notes they concern you. Go on, and sing.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Who's at the other window?
sp.stage: Eugenia takes them. Mr. Rant appears at another window.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: My Lady, I warrant you, I must stand close.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: My Lady, then I will roar, play my Rant.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: This must be my Son and his lewd Associates, but if this were the worst I could dispence with it.
sp.stage: The Fiddles play, and Tope roars out his rant then enter Lady Maggot in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Rogues, Villains, Thieves,
Robbers, Murtherers, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Hold, does the Lady treat from her Castle?

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Villains, Thieves, be gone.
sp.stage: They sing and roar. Mr. Rant retires.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Who's there? Follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Come on Bell-weather of that Flock of Rascals.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: Come Cuckolds, come on Cuckolds.
sp.stage: [The Constable and watch run, & all fall over a Line set cross the street, & tumble over one another, Sir Will. and the rest fall on them, & cudgel them lustily, they roar out Murther.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow, knock 'em down.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Here is a Stratagem for ye.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Fall on the Rogues, have at the Dogs.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Rant holding the door of the House in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: Heaven! what will become of this! We shall have murther here, Sir William, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: The door opens and I am call'd, this must be from the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: I must sneak away, Tope you must along with me, you may do me great service and your self too.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: You may be sure I shall be civil to my self, what e're I am to you.
sp.stage: Exeunt Tope, Wildfire and their Servants: But Ralph & two Footmen of Sir W. remain.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Tis I, follow me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: If Lucifer should lead me into this House, I would follow him.
sp.stage: Exeunt Mr. Rant and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: What are become of these Rogues that have maul'd us?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Mr. Constable, the Hectorly Rogues that fell upon you, run into the next street, and now they have lighted their Flambeaux, and are coming in Triumph over you, I and my fellow servants came just now out of my Masters house, the Justice, to assist you: Here's another Stratagem to get off without bloody Pates.
sp.stage: A sight of Flambeaux and a noise of Fiddles.
Enter Whachum, Bluster and Dingboy, and Servants, and Fiddles, roaring singing, and playing.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Have we met you again Rogues? you shall not escape this bout, knock 'em down.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: We are civilly serenading.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We'll serenade ye, do you lay snares for us, and beat us when we are down?

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: What a Devil does he mean now?
sp.stage: They fight, the Constable & his Watch beat Whachum and the rest, till the blood runs about their Faces, and take 'em Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Knock 'em down.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Away with them, away with them.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: Why, Mr. Constable—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Come Rascals, what do you prate? away with them, 'tis Day-light.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: Damn'd Luck, but 'tis Fortune de la guerre.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Rant, leading Sir William by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Whether do you lead me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Into full light, if you dare look upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Oh Heaven, my Father!

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: I wonder not at your surprise, if there be left
But any Seeds of Ingenuity
Within thy hardened Breast, thou could'st not bear
The sight of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: It is with great confusion,
That I behold you now, I hardly dare
Implore your blessing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Heaven turn your heart:
I am glad at least, you appear so much asham'd,
For Shame for Faults ● one good step to Wisdom;
But what hope can I have, that one short Moment
Can make you turn from your long course of Lewdness,
Such Lewdness as I am asham'd to think of:
Such mean, such foolish Lewdness as has made
Your Name too scandalous for a civil Mouth,
When but even now I saw you in your Pranks——

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Tis the last time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Till wicked drink possesses you again,
That bane to Vertue and to common Sense,
That makes you live in a continued Mist,
Without the benefit of one clear thought;
Nature has prudently contrived each Man,
In the worst miseries of humane Life
Would be himself, and I would be I still,
But sordid Drunkenness makes you differ more
From your lov'd self, than from another Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: You rouse me, Sir, out of a Lethargy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Ye think your selves the finest Gentlemen,
When you are most to be despised or pitty'd,
Not Monkeys can be more ridiculous,
Besides the Infamy you most contract,
In the opinion of the good and wise,
As soon I'd choose a Madman for a Friend,
You vomit secrets, when o'recharg'd with Wine,
You often quarrel with the best of Friends:
And she must be as bold as is a Lioness,
Who takes you for a Husband: Drink in short:
Provokes you to all Folly, to all Vice,
Till you become a Nusance to Mankind;
You'll say they are men of Wit, but have a care
Of a great Wit, who has no Understanding.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: You speak, Sir, like an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: By Drunkeness you are useless at the best,
Unless as Flys or humble Bees, meer Drones.
What Office is there in a Common-wealth,
A Drunkard can sustain? Unless it be one,
To be a Strainer through which Claret runs,
Your Nerves you weaken, and you drown your Minds;
You're all meer Sops in Wine, your Brains are Bogs;
A Toast is equal to a common Drunkard:
You'll say you have Courage, No, it is not Valour;
Valour is joyn'd with Vertue, never prostitute,
But sacred, and employ'd to just Defence
Of Prince and Country, and the best of Friends,
With necessary vindication of our Honour:
Yours is a brutal Fierceness that annoys
Mankind, and makes 'em fear and hate you too.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: These are unanswerable Truths.

sp.speaker: M. Rant.
sp.l: The use of common Whores is most pernicious,
By which, the least you venture is your Nose
And private ones you cannot gain, without
Being a most perfidious Knave, and striking
At the very Root of all Morality.
Have I with such Tenderness bred you up?
With such great care and vast Expence, infused
Whatever you were capable of receiving,
Taught you all Arts that could adorn a Gentleman:
None with such care could cultivate a Plant.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: All this with humble Gratitude I confess.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Heaven had endued you with sufficient Wit
And Parts, and you, in spight of these Advantages,
Which might have made you famous in your Country,
To make your self lewd, even to a Proverb!
Is this your sence of Honour, and is this
Your Gratitude to me, after such great Indulgence,
Such good Advice, such tender Love, as I
Have so long shew'd you? You have so often
Set my Eyes on flowing, that I have wondred
Whence the Moysture came that could supply them.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Good Sir no more you'll break my Heart,
Gentle and kind Reproof I cannot bear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant
sp.l: I gave you such an ample Income,
'Twould have sufficed the most extravagant,
Except your self, and when the Court had offered
Knighthood to me, I made it be bestowed
On you, Not that I think it much of Value,
Unless it be conferr'd for Merit, but a bait
For women. All this in order to a Wife
I did, and you ungrateful.—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: No more, Sir, dear and honoured Sir, pray no more,
You've melted me, and wrought a passion in me,
Which hitherto I've never felt, pray trust me,
And I will be what you will have me,
And, such as you shall never blush to own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Oh Will, that this conversion were but perfect;
Yet, as it is, I cannot but embrace
And weep over thee.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.l: Oh, best of Fathers, believe me or you kill me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Come then into my Arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: I will soon convince you I am
Sincere, for though you have finish'd my
Repentance, another had begun it.
I had fix'd upon the most charming Creature in the World
To be my Wife, and with your assistance, have no
Reason to doubt of success; one, Sir, whom you'll
Approve.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Dear Will, who is it?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: It is my Cousin Eugenia, who to avoid the Tyranny of her Mother, which has been very barbarous, resolves to choose you her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: This, this, compleats my joy, and I shall dote upon thee more than e're I griev'd for thee.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Oh, wicked creature, most abandon'd wretch, how darest thou be so impudent to come within my House, after the great confusion yesterday, and the uproar thou hast made to Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: Sister, if thou wilt pardon this, I'll pass my honour he shall never do it more, 'twas I now brought him in.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: You are a fine easie Father if you can hope for his amendment, but I'll see my Daughters safe; though he has by craft gotten the Key, I have a Watch upon them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: What does she mean?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: There is a Messenger below will not be answer'd, he has sent up this Letter by me, but he says he must speak with you, it is a business that concerns you nearly.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Thus early in the Morning, I'll lay my Life, it is to give me notice of some lewd design of my Rebellious Daughters. Hah, from Mr. Wild-fire: O let me contain my self.
sp.stage: Reads. I have commanded my Servant to wait this Morning; till your door be open, to deliver this humble Billet.
sp.p: Where is the Messenger? I must leave you for a while; Brother, pray dispatch your Lewd Son out of the House: but I have set Centinels upon my Daughters.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: They shall be safe for him, I give you my Honour.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh dear, dear Wildfire, thou art a Man of Honour; come, Lettice, bring me to the Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: 'Tis time for you to rest Will, and I'll repose a while.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sir, let me beg of you not to sleep yet, my Lady has a wicked design of sending her Daughters into the Country this morning, to keep them Prisoners as she did before; I have, indeed, provided for a Rescue, but if you please, I had rather have it done a fairer way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Well, Son, we will consult about it in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p:
A Pox on't, this has been a damn'd sober Night, I shall be sick after it; this is your Love, with a Murrain: A Drunkard, and in Love! You will
be as bad company as a Green-sickness'd Chamber-maid; nay, worse, for she, perhaps, may be perswaded to take her Cure, Love; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am convinc'd, a man will certainly have it e're he dyes, as the small Pox; look to it, Iack, yet.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Heav'n send me the great ones rather, without the help of Sarsa, Guyacum or Mercury; but prithee, what service can I do thee, Tom?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The truth is, Iack, I have sent a Billet to the Lady you would have Ravish'd yesterday and cry'd; she will come, I believe, very suddenly, hither. Will Rant and I, have some designs upon her Daughters, which we cannot effect without her absence. When she comes, I will make way for thee.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Prithee, Tom, let me have a young Wench, I am fit for her now.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If thou hast not love for her, I am sure thou hast malice enough for her; satisfie which passion thou wilt, so thou keepest her from interrupting us.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Ha, this is no ill design, hah; I'll serve you in this, if she thinks me not too old to please her; I am sure I am young enough to scandalize her. Most of the young fellows now make love more for Vanity than Lust; they have more of the first, and less of the last, than any Generation since the Conquest.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The decrepid young fools, were gotten when slavery was breaking in; and indeed, by their education, were fitted for it; they have no vigour in 'em. [Knocking at the door.] Hark! She's come; she's a Lady of very just dealing, and answers a ●ill of Love at sight. Iack, do thou retire, I'll come to thee instantly.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: I will; but d'ee hear, Tom, fair play.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Upon my Honour.
Dear, sweet Madam, I am transported beyond my senses.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: If I had not believed you to be a Man of shining honour, I would not have ventur'd for the World.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Sweet Madam, your Ladyship is come so much earlier than I could have suspected, that I must go and take order, that no body comes into my House, and confine my Servants to their several Posts.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.p: Sweet Sir, you deserve to be trusted by a Lady. Oh, thou dear creature, my heart and eyes yet never felt such charms.
sp.stage: [Ex. Wildfire hastily and locks the Lady in; she walks up and down.

sp.speaker: Hark!
sp.l: I here him coming, I'll catch him at the door. My dear, dear Strephon.
sp.stage: Enter Tope, La. Mag. hastily embraces him, taking for Wildfire.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: My dear, dear Phillis.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Ah, who's here, Old Satan.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: I thought you had been past the Age of squeaking.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Devil, how camest thou here?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Sweet Lady, how camest thou here?

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Abused, betrayed, undone, by Heav'n; they shall not live who have done this.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Oh, Madam, Ladies should not kill but with their Eyes.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: This Wildfire promised me assistance, to send my vile rebellious Daughters into the Country, and sent for me, telling me all was ready.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: He was not you see, but you shall find me so.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh Belzebub incarnate, I am confident he is a man of Honour, thou hast betray'd him; see in what Confusion I am in.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: He is a man of Honour, and knowing the great Passion I have for your Ladyship contrived this Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: What pimp for thee? and a man of Honour!

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Pimp is a foul word, Pimps are Rogues; but men of Honour assist one another in these necessary matters, and take it for a point of Honour.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Where's the Key then, let me out thou old decrepit Tost.

sp.speaker: Tope:
sp.l: Hold there, I have some urgent business with you here.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Had I a Dagger or a Bodkin I would dispatch my self and him.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: And for old, if I don't convince you, have at you.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Ah ah, murther, help, help.
sp.stage: He runs at her, & kisses her.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: She squeaks like one of Sixteen, if she could but look so too, I should be more sharp set; Come sweet Madam, let us be more familiar.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Stand off thou driveling Drunkard, or I'll scratch thy eyes out.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: I can make love like a man, but not like a Cat, I can't caterwaul.
sp.stage: Tope catches hold on her Hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Oh vile, perfidious Villain! Wildfire.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Look you sweet Lady, I can secure my Eyes against your Hands, ah could I have as well defended my poor Heart, against your Eyes, you had not visited this place.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Villain let go my Hands.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Madam let go my Heart, in short Madam, I am in Love, here's an Opportunity, and I will not be baffled, we must come to a close fight.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Avoid thou worst of Devils.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: If Ladies will be civil, Iack Tope can be so too, but if not, though he uses not his Hands, yet he can use his Tongue and publish Frailties on so; consider, be not perverse, come, come, nay don't put me to wrestle, if you put me to two Exercises, I may fail you at one.
sp.stage: [They struggle, she gets loose, and runs to the Sword & draws it, & runs at him.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.l: Oh impudent old Devil!

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Hold hold, Sword and Eyes are too much, for my single Weapon.
Fare you well.
sp.stage: He runs out, and locks her in.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh Heaven and Earth he has lockt me in! Oh damn'd Villain, Villain! Wildfire, let me see if I can make any body hear out of the Window, I shall run mad, Confusion seize these Rascals.

div.stage: Enter Eugenia, Clara, Mr. Rant, and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why Sir, do you make this so nice a point of Honour? when you may save us two from Ruin.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Sir on my Knees I beg your Protection.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And I on mine, or I by all that's good, will fling my self on any one, that will defend me from my Tyrant Mother.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I cannot, will not, bear her Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Can so much Beauty be deny'd Sir?

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: Ladies your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Who is this, Son?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Mr. Wildfire, you knew his Father, a man of Quality and of great Estate, who is a convert to that Lady, as I am made to this.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: I knew him well, he was a sober honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Sober and honest! Gad take me that's impossible.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: My old Acquaintance! Mr. Tope your Servant.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Mr. Rant, a Miracle! who thought to have seen you here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: You will have your Jest still.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: No faith I am in earnest, I have known an honest man that could not, but I never knew one honest that would not drink, Knaves durst not trust themselves with drink, it draws the Scene, and discovers them.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: How the Devil came you here?

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: You left me with the Devil, she whipt out my Sword, and if I had not run away, had run me through, but I left her safe, here's the Key.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Good sweet Uncle, consider our sad case, and give an Answer.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Ladies now is the time, your Mother's absent, and is safe for some time, if you will take this opportunity, there's a Coach and Six, and half a score men well armed and mounted, Sir Williams and my Servants, that will conduct you where you please.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: We are obliged to you Sir, but I fear the Reputation of such an Escape would be worse than our Confinement.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Sir I beseech you, consider and accept of their Guardianship.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Now Sir or never, make us happy in your care of us, for let my Sister be as scrupulous as she will, I will lay hold on these Gentlemens favour, and fly any where, so it be from my Mother; but Gentlemen we must not have you with us.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Well my fair Nieces I'll protect ye, on my honor be it.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: We fling our selves wholly on you Sir,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: We trust your Honour, and will in every thing obey you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: I never will command, but what you please.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Now Madam you are happy, will you not pity my case, who still am miserable.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Would you wish me to love any man till I am assured he loves himself, you now are your own greatest Enemy.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Since I hope you will now be more easy of access, I shall with the greatest Duty and Respect I can, make approaches regularly, and show you I am become another man.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: E're I shall have the Impudence to beg one Favour of you, I shall be glad to hear of your amendment Sir.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Why Tom, Tom, this is a vile repenting strein, as if thou wert showing thy parts at the Gallows, why dost thou not lay this Lewdness upon Sabath breaking.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: And ill Company Iack, Old Seducers and Corrupters.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Will you be still hard hearted, this is a day of Jubilee, and you should do some generous Act of Mercy.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: No, there is a great deal to be said, and a great deal to be done, I must see a Sample of your New Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: My Life is in your Hand, dispose of it, and direct it as you please.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: You call this Love now, all Cant, Cant, and sillyer than Gypsies Cant: what a Pox you are none of you in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Oh Brother good morrow, how do you, I was typsied last night, but they tell me you were disturb'd with Roysters, and scowreing Rogues, I protest and vow I never heard them, but the Constable has brought them before me, here in the House, I'll order them. Hah Gentleman he does not mean you, are you brought by the Constable? Oh here he is.
sp.stage: Enter Constable, Guard, with Whachum, Bluster, Dingboy, with black Patches upon their Wounds.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Here are the Scowrers that beat us, and wounded us, there are two of my Watch almost kill'd, and several lam'd, they broke Windows, roar'd and disturb'd your Worship too, all Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Oh Heaven, my Nephew! Oh Villain, profligate Villain, my Nephew! But you shall find Justice is blind, do you remember Rogues, what you did, beat me, and lam'd me.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: What a Pox care I, why did you come in the way of our Scowring? Prithee old Nuncle content your self, I am out of your Hands, and I will fling off the remainder of your City breeding, and swagger, roar and scowre, like a Gentleman of the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Here Clerk, make their Mittimus, and I'll send 'em to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: I think Sir, you are one of those Gentlemen, that we beat and kick'd very much, last Night.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Send me to Newgate? Let me speak in your Ear, how much Treason did you talk before me and my Friends?

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: What Healths and Confusions did you drink?

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.p: What secret Correspondence, and who invited the French Fleet last summer?

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.l: By these ten bones, all shall out if you presume.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: I shall be hang'd. What says the Rogue? Go out Constable and Watch into the next Room, leave your Prisoner.
sp.stage: Enter La. Mag. in a Fury.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Oh Heaven and Earth are they here! betray'd, abused, most villanously abused! Oh thou old Devil in Grain, and thou worst of all, thou base dishonourable Rascal.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Why Chicken, Chicken.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Make their Mittimus, I'll give you sufficient Reason, sit in your Seat of Justice, and give me my Oath.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: I will Chicken, I will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Madam let me advise you, you will suffer in your Honour. This Ring will be testimony.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: I'll swear you stole it from me, and you shall be hang'd for it:

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Tope and my man are better evidence, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Mag.
sp.l: Thou most detestable malicious toad.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.l: Stir not this matter farther, if you do I'll tell all I know, and more.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: What has my rashness brought me to, I will run into a mad-house, and never see the world again.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: Why Chicken, I am ready, lay thy pretty hand on the book.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: Hold Madam, pray make good your bargain with me, did not I agree to give you 5000l. for one of your Daughters.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: Out you impudent Rascal; does all the world conspire-against me!
sp.stage: She takes the Cane out of her Husbands hands and beats Whachum.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.p: What a Pox, what a Devil are you mad? Ounds I'll turn again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Sister, sister, I beseech you contain your self.

sp.speaker: Lady Mag.
sp.p: I cannot contain, will not contain, Flesh and Blood cannot contain, never Lady was so betray'd, abused, and disappointed; Hell take you all.

sp.speaker: Prisc.
sp.p: Oh Ladies have pity on me, I believe some Rogue that had a mind to marry me, gave me Deutery last Night, and I was disguis'd and lost the Key too, and my Lady has discharged me, to beg in my old Age.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.l: Fear not, we'll provide for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Will you not provide for me, Madam, or at least give me some hopes.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: And can you, Madam, can you have the heart to use your Conquest to destroy me?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: I know of no conquest of mine, nor will I believe it till I see you have conquer'd your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: What time will it require to satisfie you of my conversion?

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: Why you must be at least a years Probationer before you enter into the vow of Chastity, if I believe you then.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Twill be a thousand without you, Madam, I hope you will relent.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: It must be a Year at least, and then, for ought I know, you may serve longer.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: You are absolute, and must govern me, I'll strive by all the Services. I can to mollify your Heart.

sp.speaker: Eugen.
sp.p: The Pomps and all the Vanities of this wicked Town you must renounce.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Wine, Women, and base Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Upon my Knees I vow to it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: And I for ever to observe it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: I will be Umpire in this Business, and I doubt not but to bring my Nieces to Reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: What are you disposing of my Ladies Daughters without her Consent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: No Sir, nothing shall be done without her Confent, I will convince her, of what e're I do shall be to her Honour, and her Daughters Advantage.

sp.speaker: Whac.
sp.l: Where's my Wife in the mean time? I forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Sirrah, Coxcomb, if you speak one word I'll slit your Windpipe.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: Very well, very well, no more to be said: Pox on him; I begin to hate him now, I don't think him a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Why what a Devil are you mad? I thought you had been Drolling, or Fooling all this while, are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Most certainly.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.l: And I, Iack, we must part.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, fine Fools, turn sober Sots, give over all Vanities, as you call 'em, for the greatest Vanity on the Earth, Matrimony! you may leave any other Vanities when you please, but that will stick to you with a Vengance. Matrimony ha, ha ha, there's nothing in the world worth being in earnest, I am sure not being sober, 'tis all a Farce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.p: I hope for, old Acquaintance, you will embrace this motion, reform, and live a sober Country Life, then we shall be Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Reform, quoth he, 'tis a pretty age, at Five and Fifty to begin to lead a new Life: No, no, I have gone too far to retreat, I must charge through, I'll drink like a Fish, these Fifty Years, these Fellows will be at Asses Milk, within six Months, and dye o'th' Pip soon after.

sp.speaker: Whach.
sp.p: This old Gentlemans a gallant man, Godsookes, I'll whore, drink, swagger and scowre while I live.

sp.speaker: Blust.
sp.l: Ah brave Squire.

sp.speaker: Ding.
sp.l: Oh noble Squire.

sp.speaker: Tope.
sp.p: Farewel you Apostates, sneaking sober Sots, go marry, marry, you are fit for no other purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.l: So Brother, I have lost a Nephew, you have found a Son.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rant.
sp.l: Old Habits are with Difficulty broken,
And Fools are ever found most obstinate;
But the least Seeds of Wit with Understanding.
Will in some time spring up, and grow and thrive,
And bear down the rank Weeds of Vice and Folly.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Ladies your Charms a miracle have wrought,
And early us home to our selves have brought;
No pow'r but Love could thus call back a stray,
From all the crooked Paths, to the right way.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: But where Wit, Beauty, Vertue keep the Field,
As Prisoners at discretion, all must yield,
Those Forces joyn'd, subdue all Vanities;
The most compendious way of being wise,
Is to be Convert to a Ladies Eyes.

lg.l: NOW Lady Mothers, you who frown to Day,
Will be thought like the Lady of this Play;
You'll not condemn your selves, but like bad Faces,
Loath the Reflections, and abhor true Glasses:
But know all, by these Presents; there's no way
But Gentleness, to make ripe Girls obey:
Us'd ill, if they have Beauty, Wit, or Sence;
They will rebel in their own just Defence.
You in your selves, from Grandam Eve shou'd find,
The true Perverseness of a Womans Mind,
To what is most forbidden, most inclin'd;
What sharply to your Daughters you deny,
You fire their Curiosities to try:
They think when strictly kept from all Mankind,
There's much more in't than afterwards they find.
Your selves, go Flanting to all publick Places,
Exposing all you can, your Feeble Graces,
Darting weak Rays from your Autumnal Faces.
Heav'n knows true Languishing of Eyes you show,
When e're you mince, and simper at a Beaux;
High Dresses, and rich Pettieoats will tell us,
That all your Ornaments you wear at Fellows;
Like Woodcocks, or like Teagues pursu'd, you hide
Your Heads, and think your Body's unespy d;
Your Daughters find you out, and will obey,
What e're they see you do; not hear you say.
The Gawdy Mother hates the Daughters sight,
Whose dazling Beams Eclipse her glimmering Light;
She must the Visitants but seldom see,
And when admitted to the Company,
With down cast Looks she enters, and affraid,
She sneaks like an offending Chamber-maid:
With toss'd up Head, she must be snub'd and chidden,
And Mothers dear Delights to her forbidden;
This begets Scorn, how can one stand in awe,
Of a vain Tawdry, Amorous Mamma.
Of these the Poet must despair to Day,
They will be mortal Foes to him and's Play.
While these frail Dames the Author does expose,
The Lustre of the Good, that clearly shews,
From them a Plaudit must not be deny'd,
The Witty, Fair ones, must be on our side,
So much their Power by him is magnify'd.
We show you how your vigorous Beams t'exert,
Young vicious men to Conquer and Convert:
Firm to our selves we always have a way,
To make the fiercest Beast, Wild man, obey.

div.head: Books newly Printed for Iames Knapton, at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-yard. 1691.
div.p: SQuire of Alsatia.
Bury-Fair:
True Widow.
Amorous Bigott, or, Teague O Devilly, the Irish Priest.
The Scowrers. All 5 Comedies, and Written by Tho. Shadwell.
Fortune-Hunters, a Comedy; written by Captain Carlile.
Widow Ranter, or, the History of Bacon in Viginia; a Tragi-Comedy.
Forc'd Marriage, or the Jealous Bridegroom; a Tragi-Comedy.
Sir Patient Fancy; a Comedy.
The feign'd Curtizan, or a Nights Intreague; a Comedy: all four written by Mrs. A. Behn the Author of the Rover, and Emperour of the Moon.
English Frier, or the Town-Sparks a Comedy; written by Mr. Crown, author of Sir Courtly Nice.
Female Prelate being a History of the Life and Death of Pope Ioan; a Tragedy written by Elk. Settle.
Mr. Anthony a Comedy; written by the Right Honourable the Earl of Orery, author of Henry V. and Mustapha.
The Devil of a Wife, or a Comical Transformation; written by Mr. Ievon.
Deluge, or the Destruction of the World; an Opera.
Don Carlos, a Tragedy.
Friendship in Fashion, a Comedy.
Titus and Berenice, a Tragedy, with a Farce called The Cheats of Scapin; all three written by Mr. Tho. Otway.
The Spanish Frier, or, the Double Discovery, written by Mr. Dryden. Circe, a Tragedy, written by Charles D'Avanant, LLD.
Anthony and Cleopatra, a Tragedy, written by Sir Charles Sedley, Bar.
Lucius Iunius Brutus, a Tragedy, written by Mr. Lee.
The Siege of Babylon, written by Samuel Pordage, Esq
The Sicilian Usurper, a Tragedy, written by Mr. Nath. Tate, with a Prefatory Epistle in Vindication of the author, occasioned by the prohibition of this Play on the Stage.
Citherea, or the Enamouring Girdle; by Mr. Iohn Smith.
The English Monarch, an Heroick Tragedy; by Tho. Rymer, Esq
A Congratulatory Poem to His Highness the P. of O. on his coming into England
A Congratulatory Poem to Q. M. on her coming into England.
Ode on the Anniversary of the King's Birth.
Ode on the Kings Return from Ieland; all written by Tho-Shadwell, Poet Laureat and Historiographer-Royal.
Governour of Cyprus, or the Loves of Viotto and Dorothea, a Novel, in Twelves
The Wanton Frier, or the Irish Amour, 1st & 2d part, a Novel, in Twel.

The History of the Inquisition, as it is Exercised at Goa; written in French by the Ingenious Monsieur Dellon, who laboured 5 years under those Severities; with an account of his Deliverance. Translated into English. Quarto, price 1 s.
Some Observations concerning Regulating of Elections for Parliament, humbly Recommended to the Consideration of this present Parliament.
Quadriennium Iacobi, or the History of the Reign of King Iames II. from his coming to the Crown to his Desertion. Price bound 1s 6d.

Their Highnesses the Prince and Princess of Orange's Opinion about a General Liberty of Conscience, being a Collection of four Select Papers, viz. 1. Mijn Heer Fagel's first Letter to Mr. Stewart. 2. Reflections on Monsieur Fagell's second Letter. 3. Fagell's second Letter to Mr. Stewart. 4. Some Extracts out of Mr. Stewarts Letter, which were communicated to Mijn Heer Fagell; together with some References to Mr. Stewarts Letters. Quarto, stitch'd 6 d.

Miracles of the Blessed Virgin, or an Historical Account of the Original and Stupendious performances of the Image, called our Blessed Lady of Halle, viz. Restoring the Dead to Life, Healing the Sick, Delivering of Captives, &c. Price 6 d.
A Justification of K. W. and Q. M. of their Royal Highnesses Prince George and Princess Anne, of the Convention, Army, Ministers of State, and others, in this great Revolution.
